meanings: To make something less strong or less intense, like when a loud noise starts to quiet down or when a storm begins to calm.
examples: After the storm passed, the strong winds began to abate, allowing us to safely go outside and assess the damage to our backyard and the trees around our neighborhood.
In science class, we learned that as the temperature drops during the winter months, the speed of chemical reactions tends to abate, which is why some processes take longer in the cold.
As the sun began to set, the harsh brightness of the day started to abate, creating a beautiful twilight that made everything around us look magical and serene.
When the teacher announced a fun project instead of a test, the tension in the classroom seemed to abate, and everyone felt much more relaxed and excited to participate.
During the debate, my friend did a great job of presenting her arguments, and as the discussion continued, the intensity of the disagreement began to abate, leading to a more friendly conversation.

meanings: To take someone away against their will, often in a way that tricks or scares them.
examples: In the thrilling book we read in class, the main character must rescue her brother after a mysterious villain attempts to abduct him from their backyard during a summer evening.
During our science project on wildlife, we learned that some animals, like certain birds, will abduct the eggs of others to raise their own young, showing how nature can be surprisingly competitive.
In history class, we discussed how pirates used to abduct sailors from ships to force them into their crew, which made us think about the importance of freedom and choice.
While playing our favorite video game, we had to work together to stop an evil character who was trying to abduct our virtual friends, teaching us the value of teamwork and strategy.

When I watched the documentary about endangered species, I was shocked to learn that poachers sometimes abduct baby elephants from their families to sell them illegally, highlighting the need for wildlife protection.

meanings: A place where someone lives, like a house or an apartment; it's where you feel at home and spend time with your family.
examples: After reading about ancient civilizations in class, I imagined what it would be like to live in a grand palace as my abode, filled with treasures and stories from history.
When my family went on vacation, we stayed in a cozy cabin in the woods, and I loved how it felt like a peaceful abode surrounded by tall trees and the sound of chirping birds.
As I walked through my neighborhood, I noticed how each house had its own unique character, making every abode a reflection of the people who lived there and their interests.
In the fantasy book I’m reading, the hero discovers a hidden abode deep in the mountains, where magical creatures live and secrets of the universe are revealed.
During group projects at school, we often discuss how important it is for everyone to feel safe and happy in their abode, as it can greatly affect their learning and friendships.

meanings: Abyss: a very deep hole or space that seems endless, like a dark ocean or a bottomless pit.
examples: As I peered over the edge of the cliff, the vast abyss below felt both terrifying and fascinating, making me wonder what secrets were hidden in its depths.
During our science project, we learned about the ocean's abyss, which is home to strange creatures and ecosystems that thrive in complete darkness, far below the surface where sunlight can't reach.
In the thrilling video game, the hero had to face an abyss filled with dangerous monsters, testing his courage and skills as he navigated through the dark and treacherous landscape.

While reading the ancient myth, I was captivated by the tale of a brave warrior who ventured into the abyss to rescue a lost soul, battling fierce challenges and discovering new strengths within himself.
Standing on the edge of the Grand Canyon, I couldn't help but feel a sense of awe as I gazed into the abyss, realizing how small and insignificant we can be in the grand scheme of nature.

meanings: To receive lots of praise and approval from others, often for doing something really well.
examples: After months of hard work and dedication, the school's science fair winners received acclaim from teachers and parents alike for their innovative projects that inspired everyone to think about environmental conservation.

When the local soccer team won the championship, the entire community came together to celebrate their victory, showering the players with acclaim for their teamwork and determination throughout the season.
The talented young musician received acclaim during the school talent show, where her beautiful voice and captivating performance left the audience speechless and eager for more.

As the book club discussed the themes of friendship and bravery in the latest fantasy novel, they gave the author acclaim for creating such relatable characters that made them feel deeply connected to the story.

During the history presentation, the students gave their classmate acclaim for her detailed research on ancient civilizations, which not only impressed the teachers but also sparked a lively discussion among their peers.

meanings: To recognize something is real or true, like when you say "yes" to a compliment or when you agree that a problem needs to be fixed.
examples: During our history class, the teacher asked us to acknowledge the contributions of lesser-known figures in the civil rights movement, reminding us that everyone’s efforts are important in shaping our society.
When my little brother finally learned to ride his bike without training wheels, I couldn’t help but acknowledge his hard work and determination, which inspired me to try something new myself.

In our science project, we must acknowledge the significance of teamwork, as collaborating with my classmates helped us combine our ideas and create an even better presentation on renewable energy sources.

While playing soccer during gym class, it was important to acknowledge the skills of our opponents, as their teamwork and strategy pushed us to improve our own game and work together more effectively.

As we discussed the book we read in class, I wanted to acknowledge how the author tackled complex themes like friendship and betrayal, which made the story more relatable and thought-provoking for all of us.

meanings: To acquire means to get or gain something that you want, like a new toy, a skill, or knowledge.
examples: During our history project, we aimed to acquire as much knowledge as possible about ancient civilizations, so we visited the library and searched for books that could provide us with fascinating insights.
In order to acquire new skills in soccer, I joined a local team where I practiced every week, learning techniques from my coach and making friends who shared my passion for the sport.
My sister decided to acquire a new hobby, so she started painting, and over time, she developed her talent by attending art classes and experimenting with different styles and materials.

As I prepared for the science fair, I wanted to acquire a deeper understanding of renewable energy, so I conducted experiments and researched online to gather information that would impress the judges.
When we worked together to acquire supplies for our community garden, we learned about teamwork and responsibility, making sure to choose plants that would thrive in our local environment.

meanings: Having a very strong and often unpleasant smell or taste, like the smell of smoke or spoiled food.
examples: The acrid smell of burnt popcorn filled the kitchen after my little brother accidentally set off the microwave, turning our movie night into a hilarious disaster.
During our science experiment, we learned that certain chemicals can produce an acrid odor, which reminded us to always wear our safety goggles and follow the instructions carefully.
When we went hiking in the woods, we noticed that the acrid scent of smoke from a nearby campfire mixed with the fresh smell of pine trees, creating a unique atmosphere in nature.
As we studied ancient civilizations in history class, we read about how the acrid smoke from burning sacrifices in rituals affected the air quality and the health of the people.
While playing video games, I encountered an acrid, toxic gas that my character had to avoid, teaching me the importance of being aware of my surroundings in both the game and real life.

meanings: A person who cannot stop using or doing something that is bad for them, even if they want to. This can include things like drugs, alcohol, or even video games.
examples: Some students become video game addicts, spending so much time playing that they neglect their homework and miss out on fun activities with their friends and family.
When someone becomes an addict to sugary snacks, it can be hard for them to make healthier choices, even when they know it might be better for their bodies.
Many people worry that excessive use of social media can turn someone into an addict, leading them to miss important moments in real life while they focus on their online presence.
In history class, we learned about how some people became alcohol addicts during the Prohibition era, which caused many problems for families and communities across the country.
My dad used to be a coffee addict, drinking so much every day that he found it difficult to function without his morning cup, but he eventually learned to enjoy it in moderation.

meanings: Enough to meet a need or requirement; it’s not the best, but it works for what you need.
examples: The teacher explained that while my project was not perfect, it was adequate enough to meet the requirements and showed that I had put in a good amount of effort and creativity.
After carefully studying for the math test, I felt that my understanding of the concepts was adequate, but I still hoped to improve my skills before the next big exam.
During our science experiment, we discovered that the amount of sunlight our plants received was adequate for their growth, but we realized they could thrive even better with a little more light.
Although the snacks at the party were adequate for everyone, I thought it would have been even more enjoyable if we had included a wider variety of treats to please all the guests.
As we prepared for the school play, the director emphasized that our rehearsals were adequate, but he encouraged us to practice even more to deliver a truly outstanding performance.

meanings: To manage or take care of something, like running a project or helping to organize an event.
examples: The principal decided to administer a new program at school that would help students improve their reading skills, ensuring everyone had the chance to succeed academically.
During our science project, we learned how to administer a simple experiment to test the effects of sunlight on plant growth, which made us excited to see the results over time.
As the team captain, I had to administer the practice schedule for our soccer team, making sure everyone knew when to show up and work on their skills before the big game.
My mom asked me to administer the family budget this month, so I carefully tracked our spending and made sure we saved enough for our upcoming trip to the amusement park.
In our history class, we studied how leaders in the past would administer their kingdoms, managing resources and making decisions that affected the lives of their people for generations.

meanings: To gently warn someone that their behavior is not acceptable, often to help them improve.
examples: During the meeting, the coach decided to admonish the team for not following the practice rules, emphasizing the importance of discipline if they wanted to win the championship.
After noticing that her little brother had been playing video games for hours without a break, she took a moment to admonish him about the importance of balancing screen time with outdoor activities.

When the teacher saw students whispering during the presentation, she chose to admonish them firmly but fairly, reminding everyone about the respect they should show to their classmates while speaking.
As the group project deadline approached, I felt it was necessary to admonish my friend for not completing his part, explaining how crucial teamwork is for achieving our goals successfully.

While volunteering at the animal shelter, the staff had to admonish us about following safety rules when handling the animals, ensuring we understood the responsibility that comes with caring for them.

meanings: Having a negative effect or causing problems. For example, if you have an adverse reaction to a food, it might make you feel sick instead of good.
examples: The adverse effects of staying up too late to play video games can make it difficult for students to focus and perform well in school the next day.
When the hurricane hit our town, the adverse conditions caused widespread damage, forcing many families to evacuate and find temporary shelter away from their homes.
In science class, we learned that pollution can have an adverse impact on wildlife, causing animals to become sick and their habitats to be destroyed over time.
My friend decided to take up running, but she quickly discovered that skipping warm-ups could lead to adverse consequences like muscle strains or injuries during practice.
While studying history, we discussed how adverse weather conditions during a battle can change the outcome, affecting soldiers' performance and the overall result of the conflict.

meanings: An agent is a person who represents or acts for someone else, like a sports agent who helps players find teams or a secret agent who gathers information.
examples: The secret agent in the movie used clever disguises and gadgets to gather information, which made me think about how important teamwork is in solving mysteries and completing missions.
In our history project, we learned about how agents during the American Revolution helped gather intelligence, which ultimately influenced the outcome of the war and shaped our nation's future.
When I decided to become a sports agent, I realized that representing athletes involves not only negotiating contracts but also supporting their dreams and helping them succeed in their careers.

The environmental agent worked tirelessly to protect endangered species, reminding us that every small action we take can impact the planet and contribute to a healthier ecosystem for future generations.

As we dove into the world of video games, I discovered that game agents are characters controlled by the computer, and understanding their behavior can help players develop better strategies to win challenges.

meanings: Feeling shocked or really surprised, usually because something bad or unexpected has happened.
examples: When I opened the history book and discovered that some ancient civilizations practiced human sacrifice, I was completely aghast at how different their values were compared to ours today.
During the science fair, I was aghast to see my classmate's volcano project erupt in a spectacular explosion, covering the table with colorful baking soda and vinegar.
While watching the news, I felt aghast when I learned about the devastating effects of climate change on polar bears and how their habitats were rapidly disappearing.
After receiving a message from a friend that someone had been bullied at school, I was aghast and immediately felt the need to speak up and help make a difference.
When I saw the final score of the basketball game, I was aghast that our team had lost by a whopping thirty points after leading for most of the match.

meanings: To upset or annoy someone by creating a lot of excitement or worry; to make people care about an important issue.
examples: During the school assembly, the speaker aimed to agitate the audience's feelings about climate change, encouraging everyone to think critically about how their actions impact the environment.
When my older brother started to agitate the puppy by waving a toy in front of its face, we all laughed as it jumped around excitedly, trying to catch it.
The documentary we watched in class began to agitate our curiosity about ancient civilizations, prompting us to ask questions about their cultures and how they influenced today's society.
As the debate team prepared for the competition, they practiced ways to agitate the judges' interest by presenting compelling arguments that would make them think deeply about the issues at hand.
While discussing social media's effects on relationships, my friend pointed out that it can agitate people's emotions, leading to misunderstandings and conflicts among peers.

meanings: To claim that something is true or has happened, even if there is no evidence to prove it right away.
examples: Some students allege that the new school lunch menu is less tasty than the previous one, leading to a debate about what healthy food choices really mean for us.
In the latest science project, my teammate alleged that our experiment would prove how plants grow faster with more sunlight, even though we still needed to gather more evidence to support his claim.

During the history lesson, our teacher mentioned that some historians allege that certain ancient civilizations were more advanced than we previously believed, which sparked an interesting conversation among our classmates.
My brother likes to allege that he can beat me at video games every time we play, but I know from experience that I usually come out on top in our matches.
When discussing a recent news article, my friend alleged that the local park was going to be renovated, which made us excited about the possibility of new playground equipment and better facilities.

meanings: Not showing much interest in others or not wanting to be part of a group; acting distant or uninterested in what people are saying or doing.
examples: During the group project, I noticed that Jake remained aloof, sitting quietly in the corner while the rest of us collaborated enthusiastically on our science presentation about the solar system.
At the soccer practice, Sarah seemed aloof, not joining in on the warm-up drills or talking to the other players, which made me wonder if something was bothering her.
When the new student arrived in class, he appeared aloof and distant, making it difficult for others to approach him and offer friendship amidst the bustling chatter of excited classmates.
Even though the movie was meant to be a comedy, the lead character's aloof demeanor made it hard for the audience to connect with him and truly enjoy the story.
While exploring the woods, I found an aloof deer standing off in the distance, watching us curiously but refusing to come closer, which reminded me of how some people are shy around new friends.

meanings: An alternative is a different option or choice that you can use instead of the usual one. For example, if you normally have pizza for lunch, choosing a salad is an alternative.
examples: During the science fair, I chose an alternative project that focused on renewable energy, allowing me to explore how solar panels can help reduce our reliance on fossil fuels.
When my friend suggested we watch a movie instead of playing video games, I realized that trying an alternative activity could be just as fun and lead to new experiences.
In our history class, we learned about different alternative forms of government, which sparked a lively discussion about the pros and cons of democracy compared to other systems around the world.
As we planned our school fundraiser, the committee considered several alternative ideas, like a bake sale or a car wash, to decide which would raise the most money for our community.
After reading a popular book series, I discovered an alternative genre of fantasy novels that introduced me to exciting new characters and adventures I never imagined before.

meanings: To completely wipe out or destroy something so that it no longer exists, like when a powerful explosion destroys a building.
examples: The superhero in the comic book was so powerful that he could annihilate entire cities with just a single blast from his energy beam, making him both feared and admired by everyone in the story.
During our science project on natural disasters, we learned how volcanic eruptions can annihilate landscapes, leaving behind a changed environment that takes years to recover.
In the history lesson, the teacher explained how certain wars could annihilate entire cultures, reminding us of the importance of peace and understanding among different societies.
When playing video games, my brother loves to use special power-ups that can annihilate his opponents in just a few moves, making him feel invincible in the virtual world.
As we discussed climate change in class, we realized that if we don’t take action, we could annihilate many animal habitats, leading to the extinction of species we care about.

meanings: To make someone feel angry or upset by your actions or words, often leading to a conflict or fight.
examples: When teammates argue over the best strategy during a soccer match, it can antagonize the whole group and make it harder for everyone to work together toward a common goal.
In a classroom debate, if one student constantly interrupts others and dismisses their ideas, it can antagonize their classmates and create a tense atmosphere instead of a respectful discussion.
While reading a book about friendship, I learned that making fun of someone's interests can antagonize them and lead to misunderstandings that hurt relationships.
At home, if a sibling keeps teasing and annoying the other, it can antagonize them to the point where they no longer want to play together or share their things.
In a video game, choosing to betray your teammates for personal gain might give you an advantage, but it can also antagonize your friends and ruin the fun for everyone involved.

meanings: Apathy is when someone feels little or no interest or excitement about things that usually matter, like school, friends, or hobbies. It's like being emotionally "blah," where nothing really seems to catch your attention.
examples: During the class discussion about climate change, the students' apathy was evident, as many seemed uninterested in the serious consequences our planet is facing if we don't take action soon.

Despite the amazing opportunities to learn about different cultures through our history project, I felt a sense of apathy from my classmates, who were more focused on their phones than the fascinating stories we could explore.
When my friend organized a charity event to help local animals, I was surprised by the apathy shown by some of our peers, who didn't want to participate or even donate a small amount.
As I watched the documentary about endangered species, I couldn't help but feel frustrated by the apathy of people who ignore the urgent need to protect our planet's wildlife and natural habitats.
In the school election, the apathy among students was disappointing, as many chose not to vote, missing the chance to have their voices heard on important issues that affect our lives.

meanings: To appoint means to choose someone for a specific job or position, like when a teacher picks a student to be the class monitor.
examples: The principal decided to appoint a student council president to lead the school meetings and represent the voices of all the students, ensuring everyone had a say in important decisions.
During our science project, we chose to appoint Sarah as the team leader because of her excellent organizational skills and ability to keep everyone focused on our goals.
In order to improve our neighborhood, the community decided to appoint volunteers to organize events that would help clean up the parks and encourage more people to get involved.
When the coach needed someone to help manage the basketball team, he chose to appoint Jake because of his passion for the sport and his ability to inspire his teammates.
As part of our history class assignment, we had to appoint a famous historical figure to research, and I chose to learn about Rosa Parks and her important role in the civil rights movement.

meanings: Relating to water; something that lives in or spends a lot of time in water, like fish or frogs.
examples: The aquatic ecosystem in the nearby lake is fascinating, filled with colorful fish, graceful plants, and even frogs that hop along the water's edge, reminding us of the importance of preserving nature.
During our science class, we learned about how aquatic animals like dolphins and turtles adapt to their environments, which inspired me to research more about ocean conservation efforts.

While visiting the aquarium, I was amazed by the diverse aquatic life, from jellyfish floating gracefully to sharks gliding through the water, and it made me appreciate the beauty of our planet's oceans.
In our school project on climate change, we discovered that rising temperatures can threaten aquatic habitats, which means many species are at risk and need our help to survive.

While playing a video game about marine exploration, I encountered various aquatic creatures that taught me about their habitats and behaviors, making me more curious about the mysteries of the underwater world.

meanings: To help solve a problem or fight between two people or groups by making a fair decision that everyone can accept.
examples: When two friends couldn't agree on which game to play during their sleepover, they decided to ask their older sibling to arbitrate and help them reach a fair decision.
In the school debate club, the teacher had to arbitrate the heated discussion between students who had opposing views on whether school uniforms should be mandatory or not.
After a long day of soccer practice, the coach was called to arbitrate the disagreement between two players over a controversial call made during the scrimmage.
During the class project, when team members had different ideas about their presentation topic, they turned to their group leader to arbitrate and find a solution that everyone would be happy with.
In the neighborhood, when two families argued about a fallen tree blocking the road, the local council decided to arbitrate the situation to ensure both sides were satisfied with the outcome.

meanings: Requiring a lot of hard work and effort; something that is challenging and can make you feel tired.
examples: The arduous task of completing a science project often requires teamwork and patience, as we must gather information, conduct experiments, and present our findings to the class.
Running a marathon can be an arduous challenge, but with dedication and training, athletes learn to push through their limits and achieve personal goals they once thought impossible.
After an arduous week of studying for exams, I finally felt a sense of relief when I turned in my last test and could enjoy some well-deserved relaxation with my friends.
The arduous journey through the dense forest tested our hiking skills, but the breathtaking view at the top of the mountain made every hard step worthwhile.
Writing a novel is an arduous process that demands creativity, discipline, and countless revisions, yet the satisfaction of finishing a story is incredibly rewarding.

meanings: To aspire means to really want to achieve a goal or become something special in the future, like a doctor or an artist. It’s about dreaming big and working hard to make those dreams come true.
examples: Many students aspire to become scientists because they are fascinated by how things work and want to discover new things that can help improve the world we live in.
As a young athlete, I aspire to break records in track and field, training hard every day to achieve my goals and inspire others to pursue their dreams as well.
After reading about famous explorers in history class, I began to aspire to travel the world and experience the different cultures and landscapes that shape our planet.
My sister aspires to be an artist, spending hours in her sketchbook, dreaming of one day showcasing her work in a gallery for everyone to see and appreciate.
In our community service club, we aspire to make a difference by organizing events that help the environment, showing others the importance of taking care of our planet for future generations.

meanings: To agree with someone or something after thinking about it carefully, like when you say "yes" to a plan after discussing it with your friends.
examples: After much discussion about which movie to watch for our class party, we finally reached a decision when everyone gave their assent to the animated film that had the best reviews.
When the teacher proposed a new project that involved creating a community garden, the students quickly showed their assent, excited about the opportunity to learn more about plants and teamwork.
During the debate about whether we should have school uniforms, many students expressed their opinions, but only a few gave their assent to the idea after considering the benefits and drawbacks.

As we planned our science fair project, my partner and I carefully considered different topics until we reached an agreement, and I was happy when he finally gave his assent to my suggestion about renewable energy.
In our history class, we discussed the importance of voting, and the teacher explained how the assent of citizens can shape laws and influence the future of our communities and country.

meanings: To state something in a strong and confident way, making sure others understand your point of view.
examples: During the debate in social studies class, Jenna confidently asserted her opinion about the importance of recycling, convincing many of her classmates to consider how their actions impact the environment.
When the soccer team was deciding on a new strategy, Marcus asserted that teamwork was crucial for winning games, and his teammates nodded in agreement, inspired by his enthusiasm and leadership.

In her presentation about space exploration, Lily asserted that understanding our universe can lead to discoveries that may change life on Earth, capturing the attention of her classmates and teacher alike.

As we discussed our favorite books in English class, I asserted that the character development in the story was what made it truly captivating, prompting a lively conversation about different authors' styles.
At the school assembly, the principal asserted the importance of kindness and respect, encouraging everyone to treat each other with compassion and to stand up against bullying in our community.

meanings: Astute means being very good at noticing things and understanding situations quickly. It's like being a smart detective who can figure out what's going on and make good decisions.
examples: The astute student quickly realized that studying a little each day was far more effective than cramming the night before a big test, which helped her achieve excellent grades throughout the year.
During our history project, I admired how my astute teammate connected the events of the past to current social issues, making our presentation both interesting and relevant to our classmates.
When playing chess, my astute opponent anticipated my moves several steps ahead, demonstrating not only clever strategy but also a deep understanding of the game's complexities.
As we explored the science fair exhibits, I was impressed by how astute the young inventor was, using his observations about nature to create a unique and practical solution to reduce plastic waste.
While discussing the latest video game releases, my astute friend pointed out the importance of teamwork and communication in achieving success, which made all of us rethink our gaming strategies.

meanings: To say that something is caused by a person or thing; for example, you might attribute your success in a game to your hard work or practice.
examples: In history class, we learned to attribute the success of ancient civilizations to their innovative technologies, which allowed them to build impressive structures and conduct trade over long distances.
When I see my little brother helping our neighbor with her garden, I can attribute his kindness to the lessons our parents taught us about being helpful and caring towards others.
In science, we often attribute changes in animal behavior to environmental factors, like how a warmer winter can cause some birds to migrate earlier than usual.
After winning the basketball game, our coach attributed our victory to the hard work we put in during practice, reminding us that teamwork and dedication are key to success.
While reading my favorite book, I realized I could attribute the main character's bravery to the challenges she faced, which helped her grow stronger and more confident throughout the story.

meanings: Real and true; something that is what it claims to be, not a fake or imitation.
examples: When we visited the museum, I was amazed by the authentic artifacts from ancient civilizations, which helped me understand how people lived thousands of years ago.
My dad loves to cook, and he always insists on using authentic ingredients for his Italian recipes, making our family dinners feel like a true taste of Italy.
In our history class, we learned that authentic primary sources, like letters and diaries from the past, provide real insights into how people experienced significant events.
During the art project, I was excited to create an authentic painting inspired by famous artists, using techniques that made my artwork feel original and full of personality.
My friend and I decided to start a book club, where we only read authentic stories that reflect diverse cultures and experiences, allowing us to learn more about the world around us.

meanings: Authority is the power to make rules or decisions and to have people follow them. It’s like when a teacher decides what the class will do and expects everyone to listen.
examples: The principal at our school has the authority to make important decisions, like whether we should have a longer lunch break or if we need to follow new safety rules during recess.
During group projects, it's essential to respect the authority of the team leader, who helps guide everyone and ensures that each person's ideas are heard and valued.
In many video games, players often have to overcome challenges set by characters with authority, teaching them the importance of strategy and teamwork to achieve their goals.
In history class, we learned how leaders like Martin Luther King Jr. used their authority to inspire change and fight for equal rights, showing us the power of speaking up for what is right.
When we volunteer at the animal shelter, we follow the authority of the staff members who teach us how to care for the animals and ensure they are safe and happy.

meanings: To stop something bad from happening or to make sure it doesn't take place. For example, you might avert a disaster by being careful and planning ahead.
examples: The school organized a fire drill to help students learn how to safely exit the building, which can avert panic and confusion during an actual emergency.
By studying the history of past pandemics, scientists hope to avert future outbreaks and keep communities safe from illness.
When my friend noticed the storm clouds gathering, he suggested we finish our outdoor game quickly to avert getting soaked in the rain.
The teacher explained that if we work together on our group project, we can avert misunderstandings and create a presentation that everyone will be proud of.
After reading about the importance of recycling, I decided to start a campaign at my school to avert pollution and protect our planet for future generations.

meanings: To keep asking someone to do something in a way that can be annoying, like when a friend keeps asking you to play a game even after you said no.
examples: My little brother tends to badger me about playing video games, asking repeatedly until I finally agree, even though I have homework that needs my attention first.
During group projects, it can be frustrating when one team member starts to badger others for their opinions, making it hard to focus on the task at hand and causing tension.
Every time I try to read my favorite book in peace, my friends will badger me to join them outside, and it becomes difficult to concentrate on the story I love.
Asking my mom for a pet hamster can feel like a long process, especially when my sister badgers her with questions about cages and food every single day.
In history class, I realized I needed to study for the upcoming test, but my classmates kept badgering me to go out for ice cream instead, making it hard to stay focused on my notes.

meanings: Ballast is a heavy material added to boats or ships to make them more stable and balanced in the water, like how a backpack can feel balanced when you pack it evenly.
examples: When sailing on a boat, the captain carefully adjusts the ballast to ensure the vessel remains stable and doesn't tip over in rough waters.
During our science class, we learned that engineers use ballast in trains to help keep the tracks level and prevent derailments when heavy freight cars pass by.
In order to build a sturdy sandcastle at the beach, we decided to use wet sand as ballast, packing it tightly to keep the structure from collapsing under the weight of the waves.
As we studied the history of ships, we discovered that ancient sailors used stones as ballast, which not only helped with stability but also could be unloaded when they needed to carry more cargo.
While playing with my model rocket, I realized that adding weights as ballast was essential for achieving the right balance and making sure it flew straight up into the sky.

meanings: A benefactor is a person who helps others by giving money, time, or support, often to charities or people in need. They make a positive difference in the lives of others by sharing what they have.
examples: The generous benefactor donated money to our school’s library, allowing us to purchase new books that will inspire students to explore different worlds and ideas through reading.

When the local community center faced financial troubles, a kind benefactor stepped in to provide the necessary funds, ensuring that all the art and sports programs could continue for kids in our neighborhood.

After winning the science fair, my friend received a scholarship from a benefactor who was impressed by her project on renewable energy, which will help her attend a prestigious summer camp focused on innovation.

During the charity event, we learned that our favorite sports team had a benefactor who supported underprivileged children by funding their sports activities, making it possible for everyone to play and stay active.
The story of how a wealthy benefactor helped an orphanage by funding their renovation and providing educational resources inspired us to start our own fundraiser at school to support local charities.

meanings: To ask someone very seriously and with great feeling to do something, often because you really need their help.
examples: As the final minutes of the game ticked away, I beseech my teammates to give their all and fight for victory, knowing how much this championship means to us.
During the school assembly, I stood up and beseech the audience to consider the importance of recycling, hoping to inspire everyone to take better care of our planet.
When my little brother lost his favorite toy, I beseech him to stay calm and help me search the house, reminding him that together we can find it again.
As the deadline for our science project approached, I beseech my classmates to collaborate and share our ideas, believing that teamwork would lead us to a great presentation.
In the midst of a thunderstorm, I beseech my friends to come inside and seek shelter, emphasizing how important it is to stay safe during severe weather.

meanings: To give someone something special as a gift, often to show kindness or honor.
examples: The teacher decided to bestow an award upon the student who demonstrated exceptional kindness and leadership throughout the school year, recognizing the positive impact they had on their classmates.
During the ceremony, the principal will bestow a scholarship to the student who created the most innovative science project, encouraging everyone to think creatively and pursue their passions.
For her birthday, Maria’s grandmother chose to bestow a beautiful necklace that had been passed down through generations, making it a special gift filled with family history and love.
As a way to celebrate Earth Day, our class decided to bestow trees to the local park, helping to improve the environment and create a better place for everyone to enjoy nature.
The video game developer chose to bestow a special in-game badge to players who completed all the challenges, rewarding their hard work and dedication to mastering the game.

meanings: Bias is when someone has a preference for one side, person, or group over another, which can lead to unfair decisions or judgments. It's like when a teacher always praises one student more than others, even if everyone is doing well.
examples: When reading a book, it's important to recognize any bias the author may have, as it can influence how the story is told and the messages you receive from it.
In science class, we learned how bias can affect the results of an experiment, showing us why it’s essential to stay objective and focus solely on the facts.
During the debate in social studies, I noticed my classmates had a bias towards one particular argument, which made it challenging for us to discuss all sides fairly.
While watching the news, I realized that some reports can show bias by only highlighting certain facts, making it important for us to seek multiple sources for the full story.
In sports, it's crucial for coaches to avoid bias when selecting team members, as favoritism can prevent the best players from earning their spots based on skill alone.

meanings: A bigot is a person who dislikes or refuses to accept others because of their different beliefs, backgrounds, or opinions. This can make it hard for people to get along and understand each other.
examples: In our history class, we learned that being a bigot can harm communities, as it prevents people from working together and understanding each other's diverse backgrounds and beliefs.
During the school debate, one student acted like a bigot when he dismissed the opinions of others without listening, which made it hard for us to have a respectful discussion.

When I read about the civil rights movement, I realized that many people fought against bigotry, hoping to create a world where everyone is treated with respect, regardless of their skin color or beliefs.
In sports, a true team player encourages everyone, but a bigot would only support those who think like them, which can break the spirit of teamwork and unity.
I was shocked to see a bigot in my favorite video game who refused to accept players from different countries, showing how important it is for games to promote acceptance and inclusivity.

meanings: Very obvious and easy to notice, especially in a way that can surprise or upset people.
examples: During the history lesson, the teacher pointed out the blatant errors in the textbook, emphasizing how important it is to verify facts before accepting them as true.
When my friend cheated during the video game tournament, his blatant disregard for the rules upset everyone and made the competition feel unfair and less fun.
In the science fair, my project stood out because of the blatant difference in creativity compared to the other students' work, which often used the same old ideas and materials.
As we watched the documentary, it became clear that the blatant pollution in the river was harming the local wildlife and needed immediate attention from the community.
While organizing the school fundraiser, I noticed a blatant lack of communication among the team members, which led to confusion about our roles and responsibilities.

meanings: Bleak means something that feels sad, empty, or without hope, like a cold, gray winter day when everything seems dull and lifeless.
examples: The winter landscape outside my window looked bleak, with bare trees and a gray sky, making me wish for the colorful flowers and warmth of spring to return soon.
After hearing the news about the environmental crisis, I felt a bleak sense of urgency to take action and promote awareness in our school about recycling and protecting our planet.
When the team lost the championship game, the mood in the locker room was bleak, as everyone felt disappointed, but we promised to work harder and support each other for next season.
The story we read in class had a bleak ending, and it left us all thinking about how important it is to make choices that lead to a better future for ourselves and our community.
As I walked through the abandoned playground, the bleak atmosphere reminded me of how important it is to keep our neighborhood safe and fun for everyone, especially younger kids.

meanings: Blithe means being cheerful and carefree, like when you're having fun at a party and not worrying about anything else.
examples: As we gathered on the last day of school to celebrate our achievements, the blithe laughter of my classmates filled the air, making it hard to believe that summer break was finally here.
During our nature hike, I felt a blithe sense of freedom as I ran ahead, marveling at the beautiful flowers and listening to the cheerful sounds of birds singing in the trees.
When I read about the main character in my favorite book who embarks on an exciting adventure, I couldn’t help but admire her blithe spirit, which led her to explore the unknown without fear.
At soccer practice, my teammates and I played with a blithe attitude, enjoying every moment despite the challenging drills, which made the experience feel more like fun than hard work.
Even when faced with difficult homework, my sister maintained a blithe outlook, often cracking jokes that made us both laugh and lightened the mood in the room.

meanings: A bounty is a reward or prize given for doing something helpful, like finding a lost item or completing a difficult task. It's like a thank-you gift for your hard work!
examples: The science fair offered a bounty of prizes for the best projects, inspiring everyone to work hard and showcase their creativity in innovative experiments.
After the community clean-up event, volunteers were rewarded with a bounty of delicious snacks and drinks, making the hard work feel even more rewarding and fun.
In the thrilling video game, players could earn a bounty of points for completing challenging missions, which they could use to unlock exciting new levels and characters.
During the art competition, the artist received a bounty of compliments for her stunning painting, encouraging her to continue exploring her talent and passion for creativity.
The school library hosted a reading challenge where students could earn a bounty of fun prizes, motivating everyone to read more books and discover new adventures through literature.

meanings: Able to float in water or rise into the air, like a balloon or a piece of wood. It can also describe someone who is happy and full of energy, like when you feel really good about something exciting.
examples: During the science fair, my experiment on buoyancy amazed my classmates, as I demonstrated how a small, buoyant object could float while a heavier one sank to the bottom of the tank.
After winning the soccer championship, our team felt buoyant with joy, celebrating our hard work and teamwork, which brought us closer together as friends.
While reading my favorite adventure book, I noticed how the main character remained buoyant in spirit, facing every challenge with optimism and courage, inspiring me to do the same in my own life.
As we launched our homemade boats in the river, I was thrilled to see which designs were buoyant enough to stay afloat, making it a fun and educational experience for all of us.
Even in tough times, my grandmother's buoyant personality shone through, reminding me to look for the silver lining and stay positive when faced with challenges in life.

meanings: Camouflage is the way animals or objects blend in with their surroundings to avoid being seen. It helps them hide from predators or sneak up on prey by making them look like part of the environment.
examples: The military uses special uniforms designed for camouflage so that soldiers can blend into various environments, making it harder for enemies to spot them during missions.
During our nature walk, we learned how certain animals, like chameleons and frogs, use camouflage to hide from predators, demonstrating the incredible ways that wildlife adapts to survive.
In art class, we experimented with colors and patterns to create our own pieces of camouflage, challenging ourselves to make designs that would blend in with different backgrounds.
When playing video games, many characters have special abilities that include camouflage, allowing them to sneak past enemies undetected and surprise their opponents during battles.

Our science project on ecosystems highlighted how plants and animals use camouflage to protect themselves, showing us the fascinating relationships that exist in nature and the importance of adaptation.

meanings: Candid means being honest and open about your thoughts or feelings, without hiding anything. It's like saying what you really think, even if it's not easy to say.
examples: During our class discussion, the teacher appreciated my candid opinion about the book we read, as it encouraged my classmates to share their own thoughts and feelings more openly.
When I asked my friend how I did in the soccer game, I was thankful for her candid feedback, which helped me understand the areas I needed to improve for next time.
In a candid moment, my little brother admitted that he sometimes feels nervous about making new friends at school, and it reminded me that we all face challenges in social situations.
At the science fair, my group gave a candid presentation about climate change, sharing both the alarming facts and the hopeful solutions we can work on to protect our planet.

While discussing the latest video game, my cousin offered a candid review, honestly pointing out what he loved about it and what he thought could be improved, making me think more critically about my own gaming experiences.

meanings: Relating to dogs or their qualities; for example, a canine might have traits like loyalty and playfulness, just like our pet dogs.
examples: The documentary we watched in science class explained how canine instincts help dogs protect their families, showcasing their loyalty and bravery in various situations throughout history.
During our trip to the animal shelter, we learned about the different breeds of canine companions available for adoption and how each breed has unique traits and needs.
In our literature class, we read a story that featured a brave canine hero who saved its owner from danger, teaching us about friendship and courage in the face of adversity.
At the pet fair this weekend, I was amazed by the variety of canine activities, including agility courses and obedience demonstrations, which showed how intelligent and trainable dogs can be.
As we discussed the importance of responsible pet ownership in our social studies project, we highlighted how understanding canine behavior can lead to stronger bonds between dogs and their owners.

meanings: Canny means being smart and careful, especially when making decisions or dealing with money. It's like being clever enough to find the best ways to solve problems or get what you want.
examples: My canny cousin managed to save enough money from his allowance to buy the latest video game, demonstrating his cleverness in budgeting and prioritizing what he really wanted.
During the science fair, Sarah's canny approach to her project helped her win first place, as she carefully researched her topic and presented it in a way that impressed the judges.

When planning our community garden, we needed a canny leader who could organize the volunteers, gather supplies, and ensure that everyone was excited about planting and caring for the flowers and vegetables.

In history class, the teacher explained how canny leaders throughout time have used their intelligence and careful planning to navigate difficult situations and make important decisions for their people.
As I played chess with my friend, I realized that being canny was essential to winning, as I had to think several moves ahead and anticipate my opponent's strategies.

meanings: To capitulate means to stop fighting and agree to what someone else wants, often because you realize you can't win. It’s like when you finally give in to a friend's idea after trying to convince them of your own.
examples: After a long debate about which movie to watch, we finally decided to capitulate and let Sarah choose, since she had been waiting patiently for everyone to agree.
During the soccer match, our team was down by three goals, and even though we played hard, we knew we might have to capitulate to the other team’s skills.
In the story, the brave knight chose not to capitulate to the dragon's threats, instead finding a clever way to outsmart it and save the kingdom.
When faced with a difficult math problem, I realized I had to capitulate and ask for help from my teacher, who always knows how to explain things clearly.
After hours of arguing over which video game to play, my friends and I decided to capitulate and take turns picking games, ensuring everyone got a chance to play their favorite.

meanings: Capricious means changing your mind or mood suddenly without warning, like deciding you want to play outside one minute and then wanting to stay inside the next.
examples: The weather in spring can be quite capricious, as one moment it’s sunny and warm, and the next, dark clouds roll in, bringing unexpected rain that sends us running for cover.

My capricious little brother often changes his mind about what game he wants to play, going from soccer to video games in the blink of an eye, which keeps our playtime interesting but sometimes frustrating.

In our science class, we learned that the capricious nature of the ocean can lead to sudden changes in waves and currents, making it essential for surfers to always be cautious and aware of their surroundings.

When planning our school field trip, the teacher warned us that the schedule could be capricious, depending on the weather and how the buses were running, which made us all a little anxious but excited for the adventure.
During the book club meeting, we discussed how the capricious behavior of the main character made the story more intriguing, as her unpredictable decisions kept us guessing what would happen next.

meanings: A casualty is a person who gets hurt or dies because of a serious event, like an accident or a battle. It often refers to someone affected in a way that causes them to need help or support.
examples: In history class, we learned about World War II and how many brave soldiers became casualties during battles, reminding us of the sacrifices made for our freedom.
After the devastating earthquake struck the city, many first responders worked tirelessly to help those in need, but unfortunately, there were several casualties reported in the aftermath.
While playing soccer at recess, my teammate tripped and fell hard on the ground, and we all held our breath, hoping he wouldn't become a casualty of our game.
In the book we read about a famous explorer, the author described how some of his crew faced dangerous situations, leading to casualties that changed the course of their journey.
During our science project on natural disasters, we discussed the importance of emergency preparedness to reduce the number of casualties when a hurricane strikes a coastal town.

meanings: Citrus refers to a group of fruits, like oranges, lemons, and limes, that are known for being juicy and having a sour or tangy taste. These fruits are often bright in color and are used in drinks, desserts, and cooking.
examples: During our science class, we learned that citrus fruits are not only delicious but also packed with vitamin C, making them an essential part of a healthy diet for growing kids like us.
When I visited the grocery store with my mom, I was amazed by the variety of citrus fruits available, from bright oranges to zesty lemons, all waiting to be turned into refreshing juices.
For our school project on healthy eating, I decided to focus on citrus fruits because they add a burst of flavor to dishes and can be used in desserts, salads, and even savory meals.
While preparing a fruit salad for a picnic, I included a mix of citrus fruits, and I was delighted to see how their tangy taste made the dish more exciting and enjoyable for everyone.
As I read my favorite book about tropical rainforests, I discovered that many animals rely on citrus trees for food, showcasing the important role these fruits play in their ecosystems.

meanings: To climb or move in a way that is not smooth or easy, often using your hands and feet, like when you scramble up a steep hill or climb over a fence.
examples: As we explored the rocky hillside on our nature hike, we had to clamber over uneven boulders and slippery roots, which made the adventure both challenging and exciting.
During the field trip to the ancient ruins, the students had to clamber up steep steps to reach the top, where they were amazed by the breathtaking view of the surrounding landscape.
When we played soccer in the park, I had to clamber over a fallen tree to retrieve the ball that had rolled away, and my friends cheered me on from the sidelines.
While camping in the woods, we decided to clamber up a small cliff to get a better look at the river below, and it turned out to be the perfect spot for taking photos.
As the science class experimented with rock climbing techniques, we practiced how to safely clamber up the wall, learning the importance of teamwork and communication in the process.

meanings: The climax is the most exciting part of a story or event, where everything comes together and the biggest action or emotion happens, like the final battle in a movie or the big surprise at a party.
examples: The climax of the thrilling book we read in class was when the hero finally confronted the villain, and everyone in the room was on the edge of their seats, eagerly anticipating the outcome.
During the science fair, the climax of my presentation occurred when I revealed the surprising results of my experiment, leaving both my classmates and the judges amazed by the findings.
As we played the final game of the tournament, the climax came when our team scored the winning goal in the last few seconds, leading to cheers and celebrations from all our friends and fans.
In the history project, the climax was when we reenacted the signing of the Declaration of Independence, bringing to life the emotions and excitement of that pivotal moment in our country’s past.

While hiking in the mountains, the climax of our adventure happened when we reached the breathtaking viewpoint, where the stunning landscape took our breath away and made all the hard work worthwhile.

meanings: To make someone do something they might not want to do; to strongly encourage or push for an action.
examples: The teacher's passionate speech about climate change was so inspiring that it seemed to compel every student in the room to think about how they could help protect the environment.
After reading the thrilling book about ancient civilizations, I felt compelled to research more about the pyramids and their mysteries, eager to share my findings with my classmates.
When my soccer coach announced that we would have a big tournament this weekend, the excitement in the team was palpable, compelling everyone to practice even harder during the week.
During the science fair, my project on renewable energy not only compelled my friends to ask questions but also sparked a lively discussion about the future of our planet among all the visitors.
The captivating documentary about space exploration compelled me to dream about becoming an astronaut, inspiring me to study hard in my science classes so I could achieve that goal someday.

meanings: Having the skills and knowledge needed to do something well and successfully. For example, if you are competent at playing a sport, it means you can play it well and know the rules.
examples: During the science fair, I felt proud to present my project on renewable energy, knowing that my research made me a competent speaker in front of my classmates and teachers.
Although the math problems were challenging, I realized that with practice and determination, I could become a competent problem-solver in no time.
My older sister is a competent swimmer, and she often helps me improve my strokes by giving me tips and encouragement during our weekend practice at the pool.
After completing the online coding course, I felt competent enough to create my own video game, which my friends and I enjoyed playing together during our free time.
As our history project approached, I worked hard to become a competent team member, contributing ideas and organizing our research so we could impress our classmates with our presentation.

meanings: A complement is something that adds to or completes another thing, making it better or more enjoyable. For example, peanut butter is a great complement to jelly in a sandwich.
examples: The vibrant colors of the sunset perfectly complement the serene beauty of the lake, creating a breathtaking scene that inspires us to appreciate nature's wonders during our evening walks.
In our science project, we discovered that the different types of soil in our experiment complement each other, providing the ideal conditions for plants to grow and thrive in various environments.
When I bake cookies, I always add a sprinkle of sea salt because it helps to enhance the sweetness of the chocolate, making the flavors complement each other in a delicious way.

During our history lesson, we learned how art and music from the Renaissance complement the major scientific discoveries of that time, showcasing the remarkable creativity and innovation of the human spirit.
As we played our favorite video game together, I noticed how my character's unique skills complement my friend's abilities, allowing us to work as a team and defeat the challenging level more easily.

meanings: A component is a part of something bigger, like a piece of a puzzle that helps complete the whole picture.
examples: The solar system is made up of various components, including the sun, planets, and moons, each playing a crucial role in the balance of our cosmic neighborhood.
In science class, we learned that every computer is built from several important components, such as the processor and memory, which work together to help it function properly.
When designing a video game, the graphics, sound effects, and storyline are all essential components that contribute to creating an engaging and exciting experience for players.
During our group project, each member contributed a unique component to the final presentation, demonstrating how teamwork can lead to a more comprehensive and creative outcome.

In history, understanding the various components of ancient civilizations, such as their government structures and cultural practices, helps us appreciate how they influenced the modern world we live in today.

meanings: To be made up of different parts or things; for example, a sandwich comprises bread, meat, and vegetables.
examples: The science project we worked on together will comprise several different experiments that demonstrate how plants grow in various conditions, which we hope will impress our teacher and classmates.

Our school’s art club comprises students from various grades who come together every week to express their creativity through painting, drawing, and crafting unique projects that brighten the hallways.
The new video game we’re all excited about will comprise different levels and challenges that require teamwork and strategy, making it a great way to bond with friends while playing.
The annual school play will comprise a mix of drama, comedy, and music, showcasing the talents of our classmates and providing entertainment for our families and the entire community.

The incredible documentary we watched in class comprised interviews, stunning visuals of wildlife, and important information about endangered species, which inspired us to think about how we can help protect our planet.

meanings: To compromise means to find a solution where everyone gives up something they want so that all sides can be happy. It's like when friends decide on a game to play by mixing their favorite choices.
examples: During the group project, we had to compromise on our ideas so that everyone felt included, which made our presentation much more interesting and showcased our teamwork skills.
When planning our camping trip, my sister and I had to compromise on which activities to include, balancing her love for hiking with my desire to relax by the lake.
In order to decide which movie to watch on family night, we all had to compromise, agreeing to pick a film that everyone would enjoy, even if it wasn’t our first choice.
To settle the argument about which video game to play, my friends and I decided to compromise by alternating our choices each week, ensuring everyone got a turn to play their favorite game.
The teachers and students held a meeting to discuss the new school rules, and by listening to each other’s opinions, they were able to reach a compromise that made everyone feel heard and respected.

meanings: Something that you must do because it is required by law or a rule, like going to school or wearing a seatbelt in a car.
examples: In many countries, attending school is compulsory, meaning that children must go to class regularly to receive an education and learn important skills for their future.
The new law states that wearing a helmet while riding a bike is compulsory for all children under the age of 18, which helps keep us safe from serious injuries.
During our science fair, we learned that conducting experiments is not just fun but also compulsory if we want to understand how different scientific principles work in the real world.
In our school, participating in physical education classes is compulsory, ensuring that all students stay active and learn about the importance of fitness and teamwork.
Reading a certain number of books each month is compulsory for our language arts class, which encourages us to explore new stories and improve our vocabulary.

meanings: Providing clear evidence or proof that helps to settle a question or decision; it shows that something is true or correct.
examples: The evidence presented in the science fair project was so conclusive that it convinced the judges my experiment on plant growth under different light sources was the best in the entire school.
After hours of debate, the team finally reached a conclusive agreement on which video game they should play next, ensuring that everyone would have a great time without any arguments.
In our history class, the conclusive findings from the latest archaeological dig revealed fascinating insights about ancient civilizations, making us all eager to learn more about our past.
The coach emphasized that the conclusive results of our practice games showed how teamwork improved our chances of winning the championship, motivating us to work even harder together.
While reading the mystery novel, I was surprised by the conclusive twist at the end that revealed the true identity of the culprit, making me rethink all the clues I had missed.

meanings: To concur means to agree with someone or think the same way about something. For example, if you and your friend both think a movie is great, you can say you concur with each other.
examples: After discussing our group project on climate change, my classmates and I all concur that reducing plastic waste is crucial for protecting the environment and ensuring a healthier planet for future generations.

During our debate on whether video games enhance learning, I was pleased to see that the majority of my peers concur with my belief that certain games can indeed help develop critical thinking skills.
When we read the latest book in our literature class, my teacher and I concurred that the protagonist's journey of self-discovery was both inspiring and relatable for young readers like us.
While planning our science fair project, my best friend and I concur on the importance of using renewable energy sources, as they are essential for creating a sustainable future.
As we watched the documentary about endangered species, my family and I all concur that it is vital to take action to protect wildlife and preserve their natural habitats for future generations.

meanings: To confront means to face someone directly about a problem or disagreement, often to discuss or challenge their actions or ideas.
examples: When the basketball team faced their toughest opponent in the championship game, they knew they had to confront their fears and play their best to secure a victory.
In the science fair, Sarah decided to confront the challenge of creating a working robot, even though she initially felt overwhelmed by the complexity of the project.
During the group project, Lisa had to confront her classmates about their lack of participation, hoping to encourage them to contribute equally for the success of their presentation.
When the teacher announced a surprise quiz, Michael chose to confront his anxiety by reviewing his notes thoroughly instead of avoiding the situation and hoping for the best.
After hearing rumors about a friend being bullied, Jenna felt it was her responsibility to confront the issue directly and support her friend in standing up for themselves.

meanings: Congested means being very crowded with people or vehicles, making it hard to move around easily, like when a busy street is filled with cars or a packed concert has too many fans.
examples: During rush hour, the streets near my school became so congested with cars and buses that it took us an extra twenty minutes to reach our classroom.
The library was congested with students preparing for exams, making it difficult to find a quiet spot to study or even check out a book.
After the big game, the area around the stadium was congested with excited fans, all trying to leave at the same time, which led to a long wait for our ride home.
When we visited the science museum on a field trip, we found the exhibits congested with families, making it hard to see the displays and enjoy the interactive activities.
The internet can become congested during the evening when everyone is streaming their favorite shows at the same time, causing our video to buffer and slow down.

meanings: To make something appear or come to mind, often as if by magic or imagination, like when you think of a fun memory or create a story in your head.
examples: As I read the fantasy novel, the author's vivid descriptions seemed to conjure images of magical creatures and enchanted forests right before my eyes, making the story come alive in my imagination.
During art class, my teacher encouraged us to conjure our favorite memories and express them through painting, turning our emotions into colorful masterpieces on canvas that we could proudly display.

In the science fair, my classmate used a clever experiment to conjure a small explosion of colorful foam, impressing everyone and showing us how chemical reactions can create surprising results right before our eyes.

While playing the video game with my friends, we had to conjure clever strategies to defeat the final boss, relying on teamwork and quick thinking to achieve victory and celebrate our hard-earned success.
At the annual school talent show, my friend decided to conjure an illusion with her magic tricks, leaving the audience in awe as she made objects disappear and reappear with a flick of her wrist.

meanings: When things happen one right after the other, without any breaks in between, they are called consecutive. For example, if you have three consecutive days of school, it means you go to school for three days in a row.
examples: During the basketball tournament, our team won three consecutive games, which gave us the confidence we needed to face our toughest opponents in the championship match.
After reading five consecutive chapters of my favorite book, I couldn't put it down and had to know how the story would end for the main character.
The scientist recorded the weather patterns for ten consecutive days, hoping to find a clear trend that would help predict the upcoming climate changes in our region.
In history class, we learned about three consecutive battles that changed the outcome of the war, showing how each event influenced the next and shaped our nation’s future.
My little brother practiced his guitar for four consecutive hours, determined to play his favorite song perfectly for the school talent show next week.

meanings: Consternation is a feeling of worry or confusion that happens when something surprising or unexpected occurs, like when you find out a big test is tomorrow and you weren’t ready for it.
examples: When the principal announced a surprise fire drill during math class, there was a moment of consternation among the students as they scrambled to remember the emergency procedures.
As the storm clouds gathered ominously in the sky, a sense of consternation filled the air, leaving everyone wondering if the outdoor soccer game would be canceled.
I felt a wave of consternation wash over me when I discovered that I had forgotten to study for the important history test that was happening the next day.
After hearing that our favorite video game was going to be delayed for several months, my friends and I exchanged looks of consternation, unsure of how we would survive the wait.
The sudden change in the schedule for the science fair caused consternation among the students, as they rushed to adjust their projects and presentations with very little time left.

meanings: To consult means to ask someone for advice or information when you need help making a decision or solving a problem.
examples: Before making a final decision about which high school to attend, it’s important to consult with your teachers and family to understand what options would be best for your future.
When I was struggling with my math homework, I decided to consult my older brother, who explained the concepts in a way that made everything much clearer for me.

As we planned our science fair project, we chose to consult several books and articles to gather the most accurate information about our topic, which was the impact of plastic pollution on marine life.
Before starting my new video game, I thought it would be wise to consult online reviews and guides to see if it was worth the time and money I was about to invest.

During our history class discussion, the teacher encouraged us to consult primary sources, like letters and diaries, to gain a deeper understanding of the experiences of people who lived during that time.

meanings: To deal with a difficult situation and find a way to handle it without getting too upset.
examples: When faced with the challenge of completing a difficult science project, I learned how to cope by breaking the task into smaller parts and asking my teacher for help when I felt stuck.
After losing a close soccer match, the team gathered to discuss how to cope with their disappointment and focus on improving their skills for the next game.
During the pandemic, many students had to cope with online learning by developing new routines and finding creative ways to stay connected with their friends through video calls and virtual games.
As I read the historical novel about a young girl living through a war, I admired how she learned to cope with the hardships by relying on her family and friends for support and encouragement.
When my little brother was feeling anxious about starting a new school, I helped him cope by sharing my own experiences and reassuring him that making new friends takes time and patience.

meanings: To correspond means to communicate with someone by sending letters, emails, or messages back and forth. It's like having a conversation through writing instead of speaking.
examples: My pen pal lives in another country, and we correspond regularly, sharing stories about our cultures and discovering how much we have in common despite the distance between us.
In our history project, we learned that many famous thinkers corresponded with each other through letters, exchanging ideas that helped shape the world we live in today.
During the science fair, I decided to correspond with a local scientist via email, asking her questions about her research and finding out how her work impacts our understanding of climate change.
As part of our class assignment, we were asked to correspond with a friend about our favorite books, discussing the characters and themes that made us think deeply about our own lives.

Last summer, my soccer team had the opportunity to correspond with a professional athlete, who shared valuable advice on training and teamwork that inspired us to improve our skills and work harder together.

meanings: A counterpart is a person or thing that has a similar role or purpose in a different situation. For example, a teacher in one school can be a counterpart to a teacher in another school because they both help students learn.
examples: In the world of video games, the main character often has a rival who acts as their counterpart, challenging them to become better and learn new skills along the way.
During our science project, I realized that the role of the sun as a source of energy has a counterpart in plants, which convert sunlight into food through the process of photosynthesis.
In history class, we learned about the ancient Roman Senate and its counterpart in ancient Greece, showing how different cultures developed similar systems of government to manage their societies.

When we practiced basketball after school, my teammate and I discovered that our roles on the court were like a point guard and a shooting guard, each having a counterpart position that complements the other’s strengths.
As I read the book about a brave knight saving a kingdom, I noticed that the princess played a crucial counterpart role, demonstrating courage and wisdom to help him on his quest.

meanings: To strongly want something that someone else has, often making you wish it was yours instead.
examples: As I watched my classmate receive the latest gaming console for his birthday, I couldn't help but covet the shiny device and dream about all the amazing adventures I could have with it.
In the school art competition, I noticed how everyone seemed to covet the first-place trophy, which inspired me to work harder on my painting to stand out among my peers.
After reading about the incredible trips my friend took during summer vacation, I began to covet her experiences and wished I could travel to those exciting places too.
