When I saw my neighbor's beautiful garden filled with vibrant flowers, I couldn't help but covet their gardening skills and started planning how to improve my own yard.
My little brother always seems to covet my favorite books, often asking to borrow them, which makes me realize how much he looks up to me and wants to share my interests.

meanings: The first time someone performs or appears in front of an audience, like an actor in a play or a musician at a concert.
examples: After months of rehearsing, Maria was thrilled to make her debut as the lead in the school play, showcasing her talent in front of her classmates and teachers.
During the science fair, Jason made his debut presentation about renewable energy, impressing everyone with his innovative ideas and clear explanations of how solar panels work.
When the new video game was finally released, many fans eagerly awaited its debut, hoping it would live up to the excitement generated by the trailers and previews.
In art class, Lily was excited to display her painting at the school gallery's debut exhibition, where her friends and family could appreciate her creativity and hard work.
The local soccer team celebrated their debut season with a big game, where they played against their biggest rivals and aimed to impress the crowd with their teamwork and skills.

meanings: No longer alive; having passed away.
examples: The history teacher explained that many famous leaders, like Martin Luther King Jr., have inspired generations even after they became deceased, reminding us of the impact one person can have on the world.
During our science project on ecosystems, we learned how deceased organisms play a crucial role in nutrient recycling, helping new plants grow and supporting the entire food chain in nature.
In our literature class, we read a novel about a young girl who discovers her deceased grandmother's diary, which reveals important family secrets and helps her understand her heritage better.
At the remembrance ceremony for our community's veterans, we honored the sacrifices of those who are now deceased, recognizing how their bravery shaped the freedoms we enjoy today.
While playing the video game, I encountered a character whose deceased family member became a central part of the storyline, teaching me about loss and the importance of remembering those we love.

meanings: Very tasty and enjoyable, especially when talking about food that makes you want to eat more.
examples: The chocolate cake my mom baked for my birthday was so delectable that everyone at the party asked for seconds and couldn’t stop talking about how delicious it was.
After a long day of hiking in the mountains, we sat by the campfire and roasted marshmallows, which tasted utterly delectable when we made them into gooey s'mores.
During our science project presentation, we created a delectable fruit salad that not only looked vibrant and colorful but also encouraged our classmates to eat healthier snacks.
At the school science fair, my friend brought delectable homemade cookies that were not only tasty but also inspired us to think about how we can make better snacks for our lunchboxes.
As I read my favorite book about a magical bakery, I imagined the delectable pastries described within its pages, making me wish I could taste them while I turned each page.

meanings: A delicacy is a special and often expensive food that is considered very tasty or unique, like caviar or certain types of cheese. It can also mean something that is very delicate or fragile, like a fine piece of glass.
examples: At the international food festival, I tried a delicacy from Japan called sushi, which was not only delicious but also beautifully presented, making it a feast for both my taste buds and my eyes.
Our science teacher explained that some rare flowers, known for their delicate beauty, are considered a delicacy in the world of gardening because they require special care and attention to thrive.
During our family vacation in France, we enjoyed a local delicacy called escargot, which is snails prepared in garlic butter, and it was an exciting experience that challenged my taste preferences.

My grandmother always prepares her famous chocolate mousse for special occasions, and everyone agrees it’s such a delicacy that we look forward to it all year long, making those moments even more memorable.

While reading about ancient civilizations, I learned that some cultures had delicacies made from honey and fruits, which were reserved for important ceremonies to show respect and honor to their gods.

meanings: To trick someone into believing something that isn't true; to make them think differently than what is real or true.
examples: It’s easy to delude ourselves into thinking that studying for just a few minutes is enough to pass a tough exam, but preparation requires much more time and effort to truly succeed.
The magician’s tricks can delude the audience into believing he has real supernatural powers, but with practice and skill, he simply creates illusions that amaze and entertain us.

Sometimes, popular trends on social media can delude young people into believing that they need to look a certain way to be accepted, when in reality, true friendship is based on kindness and authenticity.
In the story, the hero was deluded by the villain’s charming words, thinking he could trust him, but he soon learned that appearances can be deceiving and not everyone has good intentions.
While playing video games, it’s important not to delude yourself into thinking that you can win without practicing, as mastering the strategies and skills often takes a lot of time and dedication.

meanings: To feel very upset or disgusted about something that you think is wrong or unfair. For example, you might deplore bullying because it hurts others.
examples: Many students in our class deplore the unfair grading system that rewards those who can memorize facts instead of encouraging creative thinking and problem-solving skills that would better prepare us for the future.
As a community, we should deplore the pollution in our rivers and lakes, because it harms the animals that live there and makes it difficult for us to enjoy nature during our outdoor field trips.

When discussing important issues in history class, we often deplore the decisions made by leaders that led to wars, as they remind us of the importance of peace and understanding among different cultures.

During our school assembly, the principal expressed how much she deplores bullying, emphasizing that everyone deserves respect and kindness, and we should work together to create a safe environment for all students.

After watching a documentary about climate change, my friends and I deplore the lack of action taken by some governments, realizing that we need to advocate for the planet to protect it for future generations.

meanings: Derelict means something that is in very bad shape because it has been ignored or left unused for a long time, like an old building that no one takes care of.
examples: The old factory on the edge of town has become derelict, with broken windows and weeds growing through the cracked pavement, reminding us of the bustling days when it employed hundreds of people.
As we walked through the abandoned amusement park, we couldn't help but notice the derelict rides, rusting and overgrown, which used to bring joy to families and children every summer.
In our science class, we studied the derelict shipwreck that lay on the ocean floor, learning how it became a habitat for marine life and a reminder of the adventures of sailors long ago.
The neighborhood was once vibrant and full of life, but now many houses stand derelict, covered in graffiti and litter, symbolizing the struggles faced by the community over the years.

While volunteering at the local park, we discovered a derelict playground that hadn't been used in years, inspiring us to raise funds to restore it for all the children in our community to enjoy again.

meanings: Showing disrespect or insult towards someone, often by making fun of them or belittling their abilities.
examples: During our history class, the teacher explained how derogatory terms used in the past affected people's rights and dignity, reminding us why it's important to choose our words carefully today.
When discussing our favorite video games, my friend made a derogatory comment about another player's skills, which made me realize how hurtful words can impact someone’s confidence.
In a recent school project on bullying, we learned that derogatory remarks can create a negative atmosphere, making it essential for us to promote kindness and respect among our classmates.
While reading a novel about friendship, I noticed that one character often made derogatory jokes, which ultimately drove away his friends and taught me the importance of being supportive instead.
At the soccer match, I overheard some fans making derogatory remarks about the referee's decisions, highlighting how negative attitudes can spoil the fun for everyone watching the game.

meanings: Desolate means a place that is empty and abandoned, making it feel sad and lonely, like an abandoned house or a deserted island.
examples: The abandoned house at the end of our street looked desolate, with broken windows and overgrown weeds, reminding me of stories where mysterious things happen in places no one dares to visit.
After the storm passed, the once vibrant playground appeared desolate, with swings swaying gently in the wind, as if mourning the laughter of children who usually filled it with joy.
As I hiked up the mountain trail, I reached a desolate viewpoint where the landscape stretched endlessly, and I felt a mix of awe and loneliness in the vastness of nature surrounding me.

Reading the book about the lost civilization revealed a desolate world where people once thrived, but now only ruins remained, teaching me about the importance of preserving our history and environment.
During the long winter months, the garden looked desolate without flowers or greenery, yet I knew that with patience and care, it would soon bloom again with life and color.

meanings: To detach means to pull something away from where it is connected or attached, like when you take a sticker off a page.
examples: When you finish building your model airplane, remember to detach the wings carefully so they don’t break during transport to the science fair.
In order to fix the broken chair, we had to detach the legs from the seat and then reassemble them with stronger glue.
During our art project, we learned how to detach the paintbrush bristles from the old handle so we could create a new tool for our creative designs.
While playing soccer, I had to detach my cleats from the mud after the rain, which made it challenging to keep my balance on the slippery field.
When studying the solar system, we discovered that scientists can detach the various layers of a planet's atmosphere to better understand its composition and weather patterns.

meanings: A detriment is something that causes harm or makes a situation worse for someone or something. For example, if you eat too much candy, it can be a detriment to your health.
examples: Staying up too late playing video games can be a detriment to your performance in school, as it often leads to tiredness and difficulty concentrating during lessons.
When students choose to ignore their homework responsibilities, it can be a detriment to their grades, making it harder for them to understand the material in class.
If a team member constantly makes negative comments during practice, it can be a detriment to the whole group's morale and ultimately affect their chances of winning the game.
Neglecting to recycle can have a significant detriment on the environment, as it leads to increased waste in landfills and harms wildlife in our ecosystems.
Reading books is essential for developing strong language skills, and neglecting this habit can be a detriment to a child's vocabulary and comprehension abilities as they grow.

meanings: To devastate means to completely destroy or ruin something, often causing sadness or shock, like when a big storm damages a town.
examples: When the hurricane struck our town, the destruction it caused was so severe that it devastated many families, leaving them without homes and forcing them to seek help from neighbors and local shelters.
The news of our school's budget cuts devastated the students, as they understood it meant fewer resources for art and music programs that they loved and relied on for creative expression.
After the final game of the season, the team felt devastated when they realized they had lost the championship by just one point, but they promised to train harder and come back stronger next year.
Learning about the extinction of certain animal species can be heart-wrenching because it devastates ecosystems, making it crucial for us to take steps to protect our planet and its wildlife.
When the popular video game server went down unexpectedly, players felt devastated as they were unable to connect with friends and continue their adventures in the virtual world they cherished.

meanings: Devious means being tricky or sneaky, often by not telling the whole truth or by using clever methods to get what you want. It's like trying to outsmart someone in a game instead of playing fair.
examples: The devious plan the villain devised in the story surprised everyone, as it cleverly tricked the hero into believing he was safe when danger was actually lurking nearby.
During the science project, my teammate used a devious strategy by pretending to work on his part while secretly changing my calculations, which almost ruined our entire presentation.
In the history class discussion, we learned about a devious leader who manipulated his followers with false promises, proving that sometimes those in power can be the least trustworthy.
When playing the board game, I noticed that my brother had a devious way of winning by bending the rules just enough to make it seem fair, which frustrated everyone else.
While hiking in the woods, I spotted a devious fox that cleverly hid behind a tree, waiting patiently to surprise its unsuspecting prey that wandered too close.

meanings: Devoid means having none of something or being completely empty of it. For example, if a bowl is devoid of fruit, it means there is no fruit in the bowl at all.
examples: The abandoned house at the end of our street was devoid of any furniture, leaving only dusty floors and empty rooms that sparked our imaginations about what life was like there long ago.
During our science project, we learned that the desert is often devoid of moisture, which makes it difficult for plants and animals to survive in such extreme conditions.
After the storm, the once vibrant garden was left devoid of flowers, but we decided to plant new seeds and bring it back to life with colorful blooms.
While exploring the library, I discovered a section that was completely devoid of books about space, which made me realize how important it is to have diverse topics for everyone to learn about.
In the video game, the character found himself in a world devoid of color, and he had to complete quests to restore brightness and life to the once lively landscape.

meanings: To devour means to eat something very quickly and with a lot of excitement, like when you're really hungry and love your favorite food.
examples: After a long soccer match, I couldn't resist the delicious pizza waiting for us, and I ended up devouring three slices without even thinking about it.
When my little brother saw the chocolate cake on the table, he rushed over and began to devour it as if he hadn't eaten in days, leaving crumbs everywhere.
During our school picnic, everyone brought their favorite snacks, but I was so hungry that I began to devour my sandwich before we even found a place to sit.
As I read the thrilling new fantasy book, I became so engrossed in the story that I couldn't help but devour every page, eager to discover what happened next.
At the science fair, my friends and I were so excited about the homemade ice cream we made that we quickly devoured it while discussing our favorite experiments.

meanings: Having strong beliefs in a religion and showing dedication to its practices, like praying regularly or attending services.
examples: My grandmother is a devout person who spends every Sunday volunteering at the local soup kitchen, showing her commitment to helping those in need in our community.
In our history class, we learned about devout leaders who inspired their followers through faith and dedication, making significant changes in the world around them.
During our school project on different cultures, I discovered that many devout people celebrate their beliefs through unique traditions, which made me appreciate the diversity of our world even more.
As we huddled around the campfire, my friend shared stories of his devout family and how they gather each week to reflect on their values and support one another.
In the book we read for English class, the protagonist is a devout individual whose unwavering faith helps him overcome incredible challenges and inspires others to do the same.

meanings: In very bad condition and often falling apart, like an old building that hasn't been taken care of.
examples: The dilapidated house at the end of our street has been abandoned for years, and we often imagine the adventures we could have exploring its crumbling rooms and overgrown garden.
During our history project, we learned about a dilapidated castle that once stood proudly on a hill, and we were fascinated by how it had weathered storms and wars over centuries.
As we hiked through the forest, we stumbled upon a dilapidated cabin, its roof sagging and walls covered in moss, which sparked a lively discussion about who might have lived there long ago.
When my soccer team arrived at the old field for practice, we were disappointed to find the goalposts were dilapidated, leaning to one side, making it difficult to play a real game.
In our science class, we studied the effects of time on buildings, and I was surprised to see how a dilapidated barn could tell us so much about the history of farming in our area.

meanings: Dismal" means something that makes you feel sad or gloomy, like a rainy day when you want sunshine. It can describe a situation or place that feels really depressing or dull.
examples: The dismal weather on Saturday made it difficult for us to enjoy our soccer game, as the heavy rain and dark clouds dampened our spirits and left us shivering on the field.
After reading the dismal chapter in our history book about the consequences of war, I felt a heavy weight in my heart as I realized how much suffering people endured during that time.
The dismal state of the school's library, with its outdated books and broken chairs, made us feel frustrated and determined to raise money for new resources that could inspire students to read more.
When my friend received a dismal grade on her math test, I tried to cheer her up by reminding her of her past successes and encouraging her to ask for help so she could improve.

Walking through the dismal forest during the rainy season, I noticed how the once vibrant colors of the leaves had faded, leaving everything looking gray and lifeless, which made me appreciate the beauty of spring even more.

meanings: To send something quickly to a place, like a package or a message, or to finish a task efficiently.
examples: The teacher was quick to dispatch the class assignments so we could start working on our science projects, ensuring we had enough time to explore our ideas thoroughly before the deadline.
After finishing her book report, Mia was eager to dispatch it to her teacher through the online portal, feeling proud of her hard work and hoping for a good grade.
During the soccer match, the coach decided to dispatch the players to different positions strategically, aiming to maximize our chances of winning against the tough opposing team.
In a race against time, the delivery service managed to dispatch the packages to their destinations swiftly, ensuring that everyone received their birthday gifts just in time for the celebrations.
When the storm hit the town, the local authorities had to quickly dispatch emergency teams to help those in need and ensure everyone's safety during the difficult situation.

meanings: To cause a break in what is happening, making it hard for things to continue as they normally would. For example, if someone shouts during a movie, they disrupt everyone’s enjoyment of the film.
examples: When the fire alarm went off unexpectedly during our science experiment, it completely disrupted our group's focus, and we had to step outside to wait for the all-clear.
During the soccer match, a sudden rainstorm threatened to disrupt the game, forcing both teams to huddle under the bleachers while hoping for the downpour to pass.
As I was trying to finish my homework, my little brother's loud video game playing began to disrupt my concentration, making it hard for me to think clearly about my math problems.
The construction noise from the building across the street can disrupt our online classes, making it difficult for students to hear their teachers and fully understand the lessons being taught.
When the power went out during our movie night, it was frustrating because it disrupted our plans, but we ended up playing board games and having a great time together instead.

meanings: To dissuade someone means to convince them not to do something they were thinking about doing. For example, if a friend wants to skip school and you tell them why that's a bad idea, you're trying to dissuade them.
examples: My teacher tried to dissuade us from using our phones during class, explaining that it could distract us from learning and make it harder to understand the important lessons she was teaching.
When my friend wanted to skip practice for the big soccer game, I tried to dissuade him by reminding him how important teamwork and preparation are for our success as a team.
After reading about the dangers of texting while driving, I felt it was my responsibility to dissuade my classmates from doing it, so I shared the statistics during our school assembly.

While discussing environmental issues in class, we debated how to dissuade people from littering, and many students suggested creating an awareness campaign to encourage everyone to keep our planet clean.
When my sister considered adopting a pet without doing any research, I tried to dissuade her by explaining all the responsibilities and care that come with being a pet owner.

meanings: A distinction is a special quality or feature that makes something different from others, like how a rare sports trophy stands out from regular medals.
examples: In our history class, we learned about the distinction between the roles of men and women during World War II, which helped us understand how different experiences shaped society at that time.
When studying biology, the distinction between mammals and reptiles became clear as we explored their unique characteristics and how they adapt to their environments in fascinating ways.
During art class, the teacher explained the distinction between abstract and realistic paintings, encouraging us to express our creativity through both styles in our own projects.
While playing basketball, I noticed a clear distinction in skill levels among my teammates, which inspired me to practice harder and improve my own game.
In our book club, we discussed the important distinction between a protagonist and an antagonist, and how their conflict drives the story forward in the novels we read.

meanings: Very upset or worried, often because something bad has happened or is happening.
examples: When I saw my best friend sitting alone at lunch, looking distraught after a fight with another classmate, I knew I had to go over and talk to him to help lift his spirits.

The news report about the local wildlife being harmed by pollution left many students feeling distraught, prompting us to brainstorm ways we could contribute to protecting the environment in our community.
After losing the championship game by just one point, the entire team felt distraught, but we learned that supporting each other was the key to overcoming disappointment and striving for improvement.
As I watched the final episode of my favorite show, I felt distraught knowing that the story was coming to an end and I would miss the characters I had grown to love over the seasons.
When my science project didn’t work out as planned and I realized I had forgotten a crucial step, I felt distraught, but my teacher encouraged me to learn from my mistakes and try again.

meanings: Diversity means having many different kinds of things or people, like different cultures, ideas, or abilities. It shows how unique and varied our world is, making it more interesting and colorful.
examples: In our science class, we learned that biodiversity is essential for a healthy ecosystem, as it ensures that different species can thrive and adapt to changes in their environment.

During our history project, we discovered that cultural diversity enriches societies by bringing together unique perspectives, traditions, and ideas that can help solve complex problems facing communities today.

At the school talent show, the diversity of performances—from singing and dancing to magic tricks and poetry—truly showcased the unique talents of our classmates and celebrated what makes each of us special.
When we read books from various cultures in English class, the diversity of stories not only entertains us but also teaches us valuable lessons about empathy and understanding different experiences.

In our neighborhood, the diversity of people from different backgrounds makes it a vibrant place to live, where we can learn from each other and appreciate the unique qualities everyone brings to our community.

meanings: Easily controlled or taught; someone or something that is calm and listens well.
examples: The docile puppy followed me around the yard, eagerly wagging its tail and waiting for me to throw its favorite ball for another round of play.

In science class, we studied how docile animals, like certain breeds of dogs, can be trained to assist people with disabilities, highlighting the importance of kindness and patience in their training.
During our field trip to the farm, I was amazed by how docile the horses were, allowing us to gently pet them while learning about their care and the role they play in agriculture.
While reading a book about ancient civilizations, I learned that docile creatures were often used in farming because they could be easily managed, making work easier for the people of that time.
In our neighborhood, the docile rabbits hop around the garden, and my friends and I enjoy watching them nibble on the grass, reminding us to appreciate the gentle beauty of nature.

meanings: To shock or surprise someone so much that they are left speechless or unsure of what to say next.
examples: When the teacher announced that we would have a surprise field trip to the science museum, my classmates and I were so excited that we were completely dumbfound, unable to contain our joy.
During the championship game, the opposing team scored an unbelievable goal at the last second, leaving our players and fans dumbfound, as we all struggled to comprehend what had just happened.
I was dumbfound when I discovered that my quiet friend, who always sat at the back of the class, had written an incredible story that won first place in the school writing contest.
As I opened the door to my birthday party, I was dumbfound to see all my friends gathered inside, ready to celebrate with balloons, cake, and games that I had never expected.

When I learned that the ancient Egyptians built the pyramids without modern technology, I was completely dumbfound, realizing how incredible human creativity and determination can be throughout history.

meanings: To gradually become smaller or fewer over time, like when a snowman melts or a bowl of popcorn gets emptier as you eat it.
examples: As the sun began to set, the light in the sky started to dwindle, creating a beautiful canvas of oranges and pinks that made us all stop and admire the view.
During the science experiment, we watched as the amount of vinegar dwindled in the bottle, showing us how the reaction with baking soda created bubbles and gas.
After several hours of playing video games, my energy began to dwindle, and I realized it was time to take a break and go outside for some fresh air.
Over the years, the number of trees in our neighborhood has started to dwindle due to new construction, reminding us of the importance of preserving nature for future generations.
When the school year started, our supply of pencils and notebooks seemed to dwindle quickly as we used them for our many projects and assignments.

meanings: To decrease or go away, often used to describe the way ocean waves pull back from the shore.
examples: As the tide began to ebb in the early evening, we noticed how the colorful seaweed was revealed on the shore, showcasing a hidden world of shells and tiny creatures we had never seen before.
During the school year, my excitement for reading can sometimes ebb, but I always find new books that reignite my passion and help me discover amazing adventures within their pages.
After a long soccer season filled with intense matches, the energy and enthusiasm of our team seemed to ebb, but we rallied together for one last game, determined to end on a high note.
In science class, we learned that the energy from the sun can ebb at night, leading to cooler temperatures, which is why we often wear jackets when we go outside after sunset.
As the summer break came to an end, I felt my carefree days ebb away, replaced by thoughts of homework, early mornings, and the excitement of seeing my friends again at school.

meanings: Eerie means something that feels strange and scary, making you feel a little worried or uncomfortable, like when you hear a spooky noise in the dark.
examples: As we walked through the abandoned house, the eerie silence made us feel like we were being watched by unseen eyes, sending chills down our spines.
During our camping trip, the eerie sounds of the forest at night, like rustling leaves and distant howls, left us too scared to sleep in our tents.
While reading the ghost story for our book club, I found the eerie atmosphere so captivating that I couldn't put the book down, even when it got late.
The old, creaky staircase in my grandmother’s house always seemed eerie, especially when I heard strange noises coming from above while no one was home.
When we visited the science museum, the eerie display of lifelike dinosaur models made it feel as if they might come to life at any moment, thrilling and frightening us all at once.

meanings: To emit means to send out something, like light, sound, or gas, from a source. For example, a flashlight emits light when you turn it on.
examples: The science teacher explained that plants emit oxygen during photosynthesis, which is essential for us to breathe and is a crucial part of the Earth's ecosystem.
When the fireworks exploded in the night sky, they emitted bright colors and loud sounds that amazed everyone at the Fourth of July celebration.
During our nature walk, we learned how some animals emit sounds to communicate with each other, which helps them find mates or warn of danger nearby.
In a dark room, our new glow-in-the-dark stickers emit a soft light that creates a magical atmosphere, making bedtime feel more like an adventure.
As the sun sets, the stars begin to appear and emit their twinkling light, reminding us of the vastness of the universe and sparking our curiosity about space.

meanings: To emphasize something means to make it stand out or seem more important when you talk or write about it, like using a loud voice or bold letters to show you really care about that idea.
examples: In our science project, we decided to emphasize the importance of recycling by creating a colorful poster that shows how it helps protect the environment for future generations.
During our history lesson, the teacher wanted to emphasize the bravery of civil rights leaders, reminding us that their actions have shaped the world we live in today.
When I practiced for my piano recital, my instructor told me to emphasize the dynamics in the music, which made the performance much more exciting and expressive for the audience.
My coach always tries to emphasize teamwork during practice because she believes that working together will help us win more games and build strong friendships.
As I read my favorite book, I noticed the author used descriptive language to emphasize the main character's feelings, making me feel connected to their journey and struggles.

meanings: To endorse something means to show your support for it, like when a famous person tells everyone they like a product or idea. It’s saying, “I believe in this and think it’s good!”
examples: The school newspaper decided to endorse the new recycling program because they believed it would help reduce waste and teach students the importance of taking care of the environment.

During the assembly, the principal chose to endorse the student council's proposal for a new sports day, believing it would boost school spirit and encourage everyone to participate in fun activities.
After reading the book about climate change, I felt inspired to endorse the author's message, so I shared my thoughts with my classmates and encouraged them to take action for our planet.
When the local animal shelter held a fundraiser, many celebrities came to endorse the event, helping to raise awareness and funds for the animals in need of loving homes.

My favorite video game reviewer decided to endorse a new game that promotes teamwork and creativity, explaining how it can help players develop important skills while having a great time with friends.

meanings: To continue through a hard or painful situation without giving up, showing strength and patience.
examples: As the team practiced for the big game, they had to endure the tough drills and exhausting workouts, knowing that all their hard work would pay off in the end.
During the science fair, I had to endure the pressure of presenting my project in front of a large audience, but I felt proud when I received compliments from the judges.
When my family went on a hiking trip, we had to endure the rainy weather, but we made the best of it by playing games and sharing stories while we waited for the rain to stop.
Even though my best friend moved away, I chose to endure the sadness and stay connected by writing letters and planning visits during school breaks.
While reading the challenging novel for our literature class, I had to endure some confusing parts, but I learned a lot about the characters and their struggles by pushing through.

meanings: To enlighten someone means to help them understand something better by sharing information or ideas, like when a teacher explains a difficult subject in a way that makes it easier to grasp.
examples: After reading the fascinating book about space, I felt compelled to enlighten my classmates about the mysteries of black holes and how they warp time and space.
During our science project, my teacher used a cool experiment to enlighten us about how plants convert sunlight into energy, making the concept of photosynthesis much easier to understand.
When my friend struggled with her math homework, I decided to enlighten her by explaining the steps we learned in class, and soon we were solving problems together with confidence.
At the history museum, the tour guide worked hard to enlighten us about ancient civilizations, sharing stories that made the past feel alive and exciting, like a thrilling adventure.
While discussing environmental issues in class, our teacher used videos and articles to enlighten us about climate change, helping us realize the importance of taking care of our planet.

meanings: To enroll means to officially sign up for a class, activity, or program so you can participate in it. For example, when you enroll in a soccer team, you are telling the coach that you want to play.
examples: I decided to enroll in the science club at school because I want to learn more about the environment and how we can protect it for future generations.
When my sister wanted to join the soccer team, she had to enroll before the deadline, which meant filling out forms and attending the first practice to meet the coach.
At the beginning of the new school year, many students were excited to enroll in various extracurricular activities, from art classes to robotics, hoping to discover new interests and talents.

After reading a captivating book about ancient civilizations, I felt inspired to enroll in the history course that focuses on the fascinating stories of past cultures and their contributions to our world today.
To make my summer more productive, I decided to enroll in an online coding class, eager to learn how to create my own video games and apps.

meanings: To happen right after something else, often as a result of what just happened. For example, if it rains, a rainbow might ensue.
examples: When the team scored the winning goal in the last few seconds of the game, cheers erupted from the crowd, and a sense of celebration ensued that brought everyone together in joy.
After studying hard for weeks, the students were relieved to see their grades improve, and a feeling of accomplishment ensued, making them eager to tackle the next challenge.
When the school announced a surprise assembly, students were initially confused, but excitement ensued as rumors spread about who the special guest might be and what they would discuss.
After the rainstorm passed, the sun came out, and a beautiful rainbow appeared in the sky, creating a sense of wonder that ensued among the children playing outside.
When the teacher introduced the new science project, a flurry of ideas ensued among the students, as they began brainstorming creative ways to explore their topics together.

meanings: To completely capture someone's attention and make them very interested or excited; to hold someone’s focus as if they can't look away.
examples: The captivating story about ancient Egypt in our history class was so well told by our teacher that it managed to enthrall every student, leaving us eager to learn more about the fascinating pharaohs and pyramids.
When my dad took me to the science museum, the interactive exhibits about space and the universe enthralled me, making me want to explore the stars and planets even more than before.

The thrilling soccer match during the championship game enthralled not only the players on the field but also the entire crowd, as everyone cheered and held their breath during the nail-biting final minutes.
As I read the latest fantasy novel, the author's vivid descriptions and imaginative world-building enthralled me so much that I lost track of time and read for hours without even realizing it.

During our school assembly, the guest speaker’s incredible stories about overcoming challenges and making a difference in the world enthralled us, inspiring many of us to think about how we can help others.

meanings: An epidemic is when a lot of people in one place suddenly get the same illness, spreading quickly from person to person.
examples: Last year, our school had to cancel the science fair because an epidemic of the flu spread rapidly among students, making it important for everyone to stay home and recover.
As we studied history, we learned about the epidemic that struck the city in the past, showing how people worked together to find a solution and help each other during tough times.
While playing video games online, my friends and I discussed how the recent epidemic of a new virus affected our daily lives, including school closures and the importance of staying healthy.
The documentary we watched in class explained how an epidemic can start from just one person being sick, highlighting the need for vaccinations to protect our community's health.
During our nature hike, we discovered that an epidemic of a plant disease was threatening local trees, prompting us to think about how we can help preserve our environment.

meanings: A period of time in history that is known for specific events or changes, like the time of dinosaurs or the invention of the internet.
examples: The Renaissance was an incredible era in history when art and science flourished, leading to amazing discoveries and beautiful masterpieces that still inspire us today.
In the age of technology, we are living in an era where information is just a click away, allowing us to learn about anything from ancient civilizations to the latest video games.
Many people believe that the current era of social media has changed the way we communicate, making it easier to connect with friends but also creating challenges in how we understand one another.
As we study the different eras of Earth’s history, we learn about the dinosaurs that roamed the planet millions of years ago and the incredible changes that have shaped our environment since then.
The era of space exploration has captured the imagination of many young scientists and engineers, inspiring them to dream big and consider what lies beyond our planet in the universe.

meanings: To make a careful guess about how much, how many, or how big something is, based on what you know.
examples: To prepare for the science fair, I had to estimate how much time I would need to complete my project, balancing my homework, soccer practice, and family commitments.
When planning our group presentation on climate change, we decided to estimate the number of trees that could be saved by recycling paper instead of using new materials.
During our math lesson, the teacher asked us to estimate the total cost of snacks for the class party so we could budget our money more effectively.
As we explored the forest on our field trip, our guide encouraged us to estimate the age of the trees based on their size and the number of rings we could see in the stumps.
While working on our history project, we needed to estimate the population of ancient Rome to understand how it influenced the development of modern cities.

meanings: To evict someone means to make them leave their home or a place they are living because they haven't followed rules, like not paying rent. It's like when a landlord tells a tenant they have to move out.
examples: When the landlord discovered that the tenants had not paid their rent for several months, he had no choice but to evict them from the apartment to find someone who would take care of it properly.

In the story we read in class, the main character faced the difficult decision of whether to evict his old friend from their shared treehouse after finding out he was not following the rules they had agreed upon.

During the school project, we learned that sometimes local governments may need to evict families from homes to make way for new buildings, which can create challenges for those affected and spark important discussions about housing rights.
The animal rescue organization worked hard to evict the stray cats from the abandoned warehouse, ensuring they would be safe and cared for instead of living in such a dangerous place.

After a long debate, the community decided to evict the invasive plant species that were taking over the park, allowing native plants to thrive and creating a healthier environment for local wildlife.

meanings: Exotic" means something that is unusual or different, often because it comes from a faraway place, making it exciting or interesting to see or experience.
examples: During our science project, we learned about exotic plants that thrive in tropical rainforests, which inspired us to create a colorful poster showcasing their unique shapes and vibrant colors.
When I visited the museum, I saw an exotic collection of artifacts from ancient civilizations, and it fascinated me to think about how different life was for people thousands of years ago.
My friend and I decided to try cooking an exotic dish from another country, and we were surprised by how much we enjoyed the flavors and spices that we had never tasted before.
In our history class, we explored the exotic cultures of different countries, and I was amazed to discover the various traditions and festivals that make each place so special and unique.

As I read my favorite fantasy book, I was transported to an exotic world filled with magical creatures and breathtaking landscapes that sparked my imagination and made me dream of adventures beyond my own.

meanings: Full of lively energy and happiness; someone who is exuberant shows excitement and joy in what they do.
examples: The exuberant crowd cheered loudly as the school band played their favorite songs at the annual spring festival, creating an atmosphere filled with joy and excitement that everyone could feel.
During our science fair, my exuberant teammate jumped up and down with excitement when we won first place for our project on renewable energy, inspiring others to think about how to help the planet.
After finishing his book report, Sam couldn't contain his exuberant feelings about the story, eagerly sharing all the thrilling parts with his classmates and making them want to read it too.
As the soccer team celebrated their victory with exuberant high-fives and laughter, it was clear that teamwork and friendship were the real highlights of the season.
On the last day of school, the exuberant energy in the hallways was contagious, as students eagerly shared their summer plans and said goodbye to friends before the long break.

meanings: To fully understand something, especially when it is complicated, like a difficult math problem or a deep story.
examples: As I read the complex science article about climate change, I struggled to fathom the extent of the impact it has on our planet and what we can do to help.

During our history class, we discussed the reasons behind the American Revolution, and it was difficult for me to fathom how such a small group of colonists could challenge a powerful empire like Britain.
While practicing for the math competition, I tried to fathom the tricky problem my teacher gave us, which required not just calculations but also creative thinking to find the right solution.
When my friend explained the rules of the new video game we were excited to play, I couldn't quite fathom all the strategies we needed to win, but I was eager to learn.
As I watched the documentary about space exploration, I began to fathom the incredible challenges astronauts face when venturing into the unknown, far beyond our cozy Earth.

meanings: A figment is something that exists only in your imagination and is not real, like a made-up friend or a creature from a story.
examples: The mysterious creature that the campers claimed to have seen in the woods turned out to be just a figment of their imagination, sparked by their spooky ghost stories around the campfire.
In our science class, we learned that some inventions, like flying cars, may currently be a figment of our dreams, but they inspire engineers to create amazing new technologies for the future.
As I read the fantasy book, I realized that the dragon the hero battled was merely a figment, representing the fears we all face when overcoming challenges in our lives.
During our history project, I discovered that some legendary figures, like King Arthur, might be just a figment from tales told long ago, rather than real people who lived.
When my little brother told me about his imaginary friend who could fly, I smiled, knowing that he was creating a figment to make his playtime even more exciting and adventurous.

meanings: To shock or surprise someone so much that they can't believe it; like when you hear something unbelievable or see a big surprise that leaves you speechless.
examples: When the teacher announced that we would be going on a field trip to the science museum next week, it completely flabbergasted the entire class, and we couldn't stop cheering with excitement.
I was flabbergasted to discover that my best friend had secretly been practicing guitar for months, and when she played a song for us, it sounded amazing and made me want to learn too.
After reading the surprising ending of the mystery novel in our book club, I was flabbergasted to find out that the least expected character was the one behind the whole plot twist.
The unexpected news that our school would be hosting a talent show brought a flabbergasting mix of joy and nerves to my friends and me, as we started brainstorming our performances right away.
During our science fair, I was flabbergasted to see my classmate's project actually create a small volcano that erupted with colorful foam, making it the most exciting display in the whole gym!

meanings: To grow strong and healthy, or to do very well in something, like a plant that thrives in good soil or a student who excels in school.
examples: In the school garden, the students planted various flowers and vegetables, and it was exciting to see how quickly they began to flourish with the right amount of sunlight and water.
After working hard on his science project, Jake felt a sense of pride as he watched his ideas flourish into a creative presentation that impressed both his classmates and teacher.
During the art class, Mia discovered her talent for painting, and as she practiced more, her skills began to flourish, allowing her to express herself in ways she never thought possible.
In the library, I found a book that inspired me to explore new hobbies, and as I tried different activities, I noticed how my confidence began to flourish with each new experience.
The community garden project encouraged neighbors to come together and share their gardening tips, creating an environment where friendships could flourish alongside the plants they nurtured.

meanings: To change in level or amount up and down over time, like how the temperature can go up and down throughout the day.
examples: The temperature outside can fluctuate greatly during the fall, making it important for us to dress in layers so we can stay warm or cool as needed throughout the day.
In science class, our teacher explained how the stock market can fluctuate every day, which means the prices of companies' shares can go up and down based on how well they are doing.
When we play basketball, the score can fluctuate quickly as both teams try their hardest to outplay each other, making every moment exciting and unpredictable.
During our school project on weather patterns, we learned that the amount of rainfall can fluctuate from month to month, affecting crops and the environment significantly.
As the season changes, the number of students attending after-school clubs can fluctuate, making it interesting to see which activities become more popular as friends join in.

meanings: To make someone feel nervous or confused, often by surprising or overwhelming them.
examples: During the science fair, I felt flustered when my project didn’t work as planned, and I struggled to explain my ideas to the judges while trying to keep my nerves under control.
When the teacher suddenly asked me to solve a difficult math problem on the board, I became flustered and couldn’t remember the steps I had practiced earlier in class.
As the deadline for our group project approached, the pressure began to fluster my teammates, causing us to argue instead of working together to finish our presentation on time.
While playing an intense video game with my friends, I got flustered by the unexpected challenges, which made me lose focus and forget my winning strategy.
When my little sister kept asking me questions while I was trying to read a complicated book, I felt flustered and had to pause to help her understand the story.

meanings: To search for and collect food or supplies, often in a natural setting like a forest or field. For example, animals forage for berries, nuts, or plants to eat.
examples: As we explored the forest during our science field trip, we learned how animals forage for food, using their keen senses to find berries, nuts, and insects hidden among the leaves.
In our history project about ancient civilizations, we discovered how early humans had to forage for food daily, gathering wild plants and hunting animals to survive in the harsh environment.
During our camping trip, my friends and I decided to forage for wild mushrooms and berries, which taught us about the importance of knowing which plants are safe to eat in nature.
While playing the video game set in a post-apocalyptic world, we had to forage through abandoned buildings for supplies, teaching us strategic thinking and resourcefulness to survive in the game.
As part of our community service project, we visited a local farm where we could forage for fresh vegetables, learning about sustainable practices and the benefits of eating locally grown food.

meanings: Something that is formidable is very impressive and can make people feel a mix of fear and respect because it is strong, big, or skilled.
examples: The formidable storm rolled in quickly, darkening the sky and sending everyone rushing indoors as the winds howled and the rain poured down in heavy sheets.
During our science fair, I was amazed by the formidable robot my classmate built, which could perform complex tasks and even navigate through obstacles on its own.
In our history lesson, we learned about the formidable challenges faced by explorers in the past, such as treacherous mountains and vast oceans that tested their bravery and determination.
When I play basketball against my older brother, his formidable height and skills make it difficult for me to score, but I enjoy the challenge and strive to improve my game.
The formidable mountain range loomed in the distance during our hiking trip, inspiring both awe and respect as we prepared for the adventure ahead, knowing it would push our limits.

meanings: To help something grow or develop, like encouraging a friend to try a new sport or taking care of a pet.
examples: Teachers often create engaging projects that foster creativity and teamwork among students, allowing us to collaborate and learn new skills while making lasting memories together.
By participating in community service, we can foster a sense of responsibility and empathy, helping us understand the importance of supporting those in need in our neighborhoods.

Reading diverse books can foster a greater appreciation for different cultures and perspectives, encouraging us to become more open-minded and understanding individuals in our increasingly connected world.

In science class, our teacher designed experiments that foster critical thinking and problem-solving skills, pushing us to explore innovative solutions to real-world challenges like climate change and sustainability.
Playing sports not only helps to foster physical fitness but also teaches valuable lessons about teamwork, perseverance, and the importance of good sportsmanship in both victory and defeat.

meanings: A garland is a decoration made of flowers, leaves, or other materials that is often shaped into a circle or a chain. People use garlands to decorate their homes, celebrate special occasions, or wear them as a pretty headpiece.
examples: During the school festival, our class decided to create a beautiful garland made of colorful paper flowers, which we proudly hung around the gym to brighten up the atmosphere for everyone attending.

As we prepared for the annual spring dance, my friends and I crafted a stunning garland of fresh daisies and green leaves, which we draped around the entrance to make the event feel more festive and inviting.

In history class, we learned how ancient cultures used garlands made of various plants to honor their gods or celebrate significant events, showing us how creativity has always been an important part of human expression.

While exploring the garden, I discovered that the vines could be twisted together to create a lovely garland, inspiring me to make a nature-themed decoration for my room that reflected the beauty of the outdoors.

Our art teacher encouraged us to design a garland for the school’s environmental awareness week, emphasizing how using recycled materials could help promote sustainability and inspire our classmates to think about reducing waste.

meanings: A garrison is a group of soldiers who are stationed at a place, like a fort or a base, to keep it safe and protect it from danger.
examples: During our history project, we learned about the garrison that defended the ancient castle, and we were fascinated by the different strategies soldiers used to protect their territory from invaders.
In the video game we played, the garrison was crucial for our team’s success, as it provided us with extra resources and soldiers to defend our base against enemy attacks.
When we visited the museum, the guide explained how a garrison operated during wartime, and it made us think about the sacrifices soldiers make to keep their homeland safe.
In our science class, we discovered how animals, like prairie dogs or meerkats, form a garrison-like community to protect each other from predators, showcasing teamwork in the animal kingdom.
During our discussion about current events, we talked about the importance of a garrison in maintaining peace in conflict zones, helping us understand the role of soldiers in global safety.

meanings: A ghetto is a part of a city where people from the same background or culture often live together, usually because they have fewer choices for where to live. These areas can sometimes face challenges like less money for schools or jobs.
examples: In history class, we learned that many cities had areas known as ghettos where people faced poverty, and it helped us understand the importance of community support and social change.

During our group project on urban development, we discussed how some neighborhoods, often labeled as ghettos, struggle with access to good schools and parks, which can affect the lives of the children living there.
While volunteering at the local community center, I met kids from different backgrounds, including those living in the ghetto, and it opened my eyes to the challenges they face every day.
In the video game we played, the main character navigated through a ghetto filled with obstacles, which made us think about how different environments can affect a person's choices and opportunities.
My friend wrote a story about a boy who lives in a ghetto, illustrating how he dreams of becoming a scientist and finding ways to improve his neighborhood for everyone who lives there.

meanings: To make someone feel happy or satisfied by giving them what they want or helping them in a special way.
examples: When I received my report card filled with good grades, it truly gratified me to know that my hard work and late-night study sessions had paid off in a big way.
As we completed our community service project, the smiles on the faces of the children we helped gratified us, reminding us of the importance of kindness and generosity.
After finishing a challenging puzzle, the sense of accomplishment that washed over me was incredibly gratifying, proving that patience and persistence can lead to great rewards.
When my little brother finally learned to ride his bike without training wheels, his joyful laughter and proud smile gratified me, as I felt like I had helped him achieve something special.
The moment I saw my favorite author at the book signing event, I was so starstruck and excited that it gratified my love for reading and inspired me to write my own stories.

meanings: Grievous means something that causes a lot of pain or sadness, like losing a pet or facing a serious problem.
examples: The grievous loss of a beloved pet can leave a significant impact on a child, making them feel a deep sense of sadness and longing for the joyful moments they shared together.
During the history lesson, we learned about the grievous consequences of war, which often include not only loss of life but also the destruction of communities and families.
When my teammate got injured during the soccer game, the grievous sight of him lying on the field made us all pause and worry about his health and well-being.
Reading about the grievous effects of pollution on wildlife in science class made me realize how important it is to take care of our environment for future generations.
After hearing about the grievous news of a natural disaster affecting many people, our school organized a fundraiser to help those in need, showing how we can come together to support others.

meanings: Very tiring and difficult, often making you feel worn out, like when you run a long race or study for a big test for hours.
examples: The marathon training program was grueling, requiring us to run several miles every day, but crossing the finish line made all the hard work and exhaustion worth it in the end.
During the grueling science project, we spent countless hours researching and building our model volcano, but when it finally erupted in class, we felt a great sense of accomplishment.
After a grueling week of studying for finals, I was so relieved to enjoy a relaxing weekend with friends, playing video games and watching movies without any stress.
The grueling practice sessions for the school play pushed us to our limits, but the performances were so rewarding that we all agreed it was worth the effort and late nights.
Even though hiking up the steep mountain trail was grueling and made our legs ache, the breathtaking view from the top reminded us that the journey was truly worth every step.

meanings: To haggle means to discuss the price of something you want to buy, trying to get a better deal or lower price than what it is being sold for. It's like negotiating with a seller to see if you can pay less money.
examples: When my brother wanted to buy a new video game, he decided to haggle with the store owner, trying to convince them to lower the price since it was an earlier version.
During our trip to the flea market, my friends and I learned how to haggle with vendors, practicing our negotiation skills to get the best deals on unique handmade crafts.
As we studied ancient trading routes in history class, our teacher explained how merchants would haggle over spices and silk to ensure they got the best value for their goods.
While planning our school bake sale, we discussed how we could haggle with local businesses for donations, hoping to get more treats and drinks to sell for charity.
At the science fair, my partner and I decided to haggle with our classmates for supplies, trading items we didn’t need for those that would help improve our project presentation.

meanings: To bother or upset someone many times, making them feel uncomfortable or stressed. This can happen through teasing, name-calling, or unwanted messages.
examples: Some students might not realize that constantly teasing a classmate about their appearance can harass them, making school a difficult place for that person to feel comfortable and safe.
During the group project, one member began to harass another by interrupting their ideas and making rude comments, which caused tension and hurt feelings among the entire team.
In an effort to raise awareness, the school held a workshop to educate students about how online bullying can harass others and lead to serious emotional consequences for those targeted.
When animals in the wild are harassed by humans who get too close, it can disrupt their natural behaviors and even put their survival at risk, highlighting the importance of respecting wildlife.
Despite the rules against bullying, some kids still feel the need to harass others during lunch, which can create an unwelcoming environment for everyone in the cafeteria.

meanings: Having an attitude that makes you think you are better than others and look down on them.
examples: During the school debate, the haughty student dismissed his classmates' arguments with a wave of his hand, believing that his extensive knowledge made him superior to everyone else in the room.

As she walked through the art gallery, the haughty critic examined each piece with a condescending glare, making it clear that she believed her tastes were far more refined than those of the average visitor.

In the world of sports, the haughty athlete often boasted about his victories, failing to recognize that true sportsmanship involves respecting and encouraging all competitors, regardless of their skill level.

While reading the novel, I couldn’t help but dislike the haughty character who constantly looked down on others, as it highlighted the importance of kindness and humility in our friendships and interactions.

At the science fair, the haughty team believed their project would win easily, but when they neglected to listen to the feedback of others, they missed a valuable opportunity to improve and learn from their peers.

meanings: To act quickly or rush into something without thinking about what might happen next, like diving into a pool without checking the water first.
examples: After hearing the school bell ring, I dashed headlong down the hallway, eager to get to my favorite class on time, even if it meant nearly tripping over my own feet.
During the soccer game, our team rushed headlong toward the goal, driven by the excitement of the championship match, but we had to remember to play smart and not forget our strategy.

As I read the thrilling adventure book, I found myself diving headlong into the story, forgetting everything around me, from the homework I still needed to finish to the dinner waiting for me at home.
On a sunny Saturday, my friends and I raced headlong into the park, our laughter echoing through the trees as we imagined ourselves as heroes on a quest to save the world from boredom.

When the science project deadline approached, I worked headlong into the night, fueled by a mix of excitement and panic, determined to create something impressive that would wow my teacher and classmates.

meanings: To pay close attention to something important, like listening to a teacher's instructions or following safety rules.
examples: During his history presentation, Jason reminded us to heed the lessons learned from past events to better understand the importance of making thoughtful decisions in our own lives.
As we explored the science exhibit at the museum, the guide encouraged us to heed the warnings about climate change so we could help protect our planet for future generations.
When practicing for the soccer match, our coach told us to heed his advice about teamwork and communication, as these skills could make all the difference in winning the game.
While reading the book about friendship, I realized that I needed to heed the character's experiences to learn how to be a better friend and support my peers in tough times.
During the school assembly, the principal asked us to heed the importance of kindness and respect, reminding us that our words and actions can significantly impact those around us.

meanings: To gather and keep a lot of items, often more than you really need, and sometimes hiding them away from others.
examples: My little brother tends to hoard all his action figures in his room, creating a massive collection that he loves to show off to his friends during playdates.
During the science fair, I discovered that some students chose to hoard unusual materials like old electronics and bottle caps to create innovative projects that really impressed the judges.
While exploring the attic, I found my grandmother's old journals, and it became clear that she had a tendency to hoard memories, writing down every special moment she experienced throughout her life.
In our history project, we learned about ancient civilizations that would hoard resources like grain and gold, believing that having more would help them survive during tough times or conflicts.
When I noticed my friend had started to hoard candy from Halloween, I gently reminded him that sharing with others can be much more rewarding than keeping it all for himself.

meanings: Homage is a way of showing respect or honor to someone, often by celebrating their achievements or remembering their importance. It's like giving a special tribute to someone you admire.
examples: At the school assembly, the principal delivered a heartfelt speech in homage to the teachers, recognizing their hard work and dedication to helping students succeed throughout the year.
During the art class, we created colorful murals as a homage to the famous artists we studied, showcasing our understanding of their unique styles and techniques.
In the final game of the season, the basketball team wore special jerseys as a homage to their coach, who had inspired them with his passion and commitment to the sport.
As we read the book about historical figures, we learned how each person made sacrifices, and the author paid homage to their bravery through vivid storytelling that inspired us all.
When my friend organized a charity event, she did so in homage to her grandmother, who always taught her the importance of helping others and giving back to the community.

meanings: A hovel is a small, run-down house or shelter that is often dirty and uncomfortable to live in. It usually lacks basic necessities and doesn't provide a safe or pleasant environment.
examples: The old hovel at the edge of town had long been abandoned, but my friends and I decided to explore it one afternoon, imagining the stories it could tell about its former inhabitants.
During our history lesson, we learned about how some people in the past lived in hovels, which were often cold and uncomfortable, making us appreciate the warmth and safety of our own homes.

As we researched different living conditions around the world for our school project, we discovered that many families still live in hovels, prompting a discussion about poverty and how we can help those in need.
In the story we read, the main character grew up in a hovel, which shaped his dreams of escaping to a better life and inspired us to think about the importance of hope and perseverance.
While hiking in the woods, we stumbled upon an old hovel that looked like it belonged to a hermit; it made us wonder about who had lived there and why they chose such a secluded life.

meanings: To move quickly and with a lot of energy, like when a car speeds down the road or when a person runs really fast.
examples: As the roller coaster climbed higher, I could feel my heart racing, and suddenly we began to hurtle down the track, screaming with excitement and pure adrenaline.
During our science experiment, we watched as the marble would hurtle down the ramp, demonstrating the principles of gravity and motion in a way that captivated everyone in the classroom.
In the action-packed video game, my character had to hurtle through obstacles and defeat enemies at lightning speed to reach the final level before time ran out.
While hiking in the mountains, we were amazed to see a group of mountain goats hurtle down the steep cliffs with such agility, making it look effortless as they navigated the rocky terrain.
As the storm approached, the wind began to howl, and the leaves started to hurtle through the air, creating a whirlwind of colors that danced around us like a wild, nature-made show.

meanings: Not having the ability to read or write; someone who hasn't learned these skills yet.
examples: Many children around the world are still illiterate, meaning they cannot read or write, which prevents them from fully participating in school and understanding important information in their lives.
In history class, we learned that during ancient times, many people were illiterate, which made it difficult for them to communicate and share their ideas with others.
Despite advancements in technology, some adults remain illiterate, unable to read instructions or fill out forms, which can affect their ability to find jobs and support their families.
The library organized a program to help illiterate adults improve their reading skills, showing that it's never too late to learn and grow through education.
As we discussed social issues in class, we realized that illiteracy can lead to a cycle of poverty, where individuals struggle to escape their circumstances without basic reading and writing skills.

meanings: Well-known and admired for doing great things in the past; someone who is famous for their achievements.
examples: The illustrious scientist Marie Curie is remembered for her groundbreaking work in radioactivity, inspiring countless young people to pursue careers in science and exploration.
During our history lesson, we learned about the illustrious achievements of civil rights leaders who fought tirelessly for equality, shaping a better future for everyone in our country.
In our annual school talent show, my friend showcased her illustrious dance skills, impressing the audience with her graceful moves and heartfelt performance that left everyone cheering.
As I read the biography of the illustrious author J.K. Rowling, I discovered how her journey from struggling single mother to world-famous writer can inspire anyone to follow their dreams.
The illustrious soccer player scored the winning goal in the championship game, earning him not only fame but also the respect of his teammates and fans alike for his hard work and dedication.

meanings: Not favoring one side over another; treating everyone fairly and equally, like a referee in a game who makes sure all players follow the rules without taking sides.
examples: The teacher was impartial when grading our projects, ensuring that each student's work was evaluated fairly, regardless of who they were or how well they usually performed in class.
During the debate club, it was important for the judges to remain impartial, as this would guarantee that every participant had an equal chance to express their arguments without favoritism.
When we played basketball, our referee was impartial, making sure that all calls were fair so that neither team felt cheated and everyone could enjoy the game.
In a group project, it's crucial for teammates to be impartial, allowing everyone’s ideas to be heard and considered equally, which helps create a better final product.
The article in the newspaper was written in an impartial tone, presenting both sides of the story without taking sides, which helped readers form their own opinions on the issue.

meanings: To slow down or stop something from happening; for example, if a big rock is in the road, it can impede cars from driving forward.
examples: If we don’t finish our science project on time, it could impede our chances of getting a good grade, so we need to work together to stay focused and organized.
During the soccer match, the rainy weather began to impede our ability to pass the ball effectively, making it difficult for both teams to score goals as the field became muddy.
When our teacher explained that distractions from our phones could impede our learning, we realized it was important to put them away during class to focus on the lesson.
The construction work on the road might impede traffic flow, causing delays for people trying to get to school or work, which is why it’s essential to leave early.
In the book we read for class, the main character faced challenges that seemed to impede her journey, but she found ways to overcome them and achieve her dreams despite the obstacles.

meanings: Acting quickly without thinking things through; making decisions on the spot without considering the consequences.
examples: During the science fair, Jenna made an impetuous decision to change her project the night before, which led to a chaotic presentation that left her feeling unprepared and anxious.
When Mark impulsively challenged his classmates to a race during gym class, he quickly regretted it as he realized he hadn’t trained for such a fast-paced competition.
Samantha’s impetuous choice to adopt a puppy without considering the responsibilities involved resulted in unexpected challenges that she had to learn to manage.
After hearing a rumor about a surprise party, Tom made an impetuous assumption and accidentally spoiled the surprise for his friend, which taught him the importance of thinking before speaking.
In the heat of the video game battle, Kyle made an impetuous move that cost his team the match, reminding him that strategy is just as important as quick reflexes in competition.

meanings: Done without planning ahead; something that happens suddenly and without preparation, like a surprise party or a last-minute game.
examples: During our school assembly, the principal announced an impromptu talent show, encouraging students to showcase their skills right then and there, which led to some amazing and unexpected performances.
After finishing our science project early, my friends and I decided to have an impromptu debate about the best superhero, which turned into a lively discussion filled with laughter and excitement.
When we arrived at the picnic, we discovered that the park was hosting an impromptu concert, and we all danced and sang along to the music, making it a day to remember.
During a rainy day at home, my brother and I organized an impromptu board game tournament, inviting the whole family to join in, and we spent hours competing and having fun together.
While hiking in the woods, we stumbled upon an impromptu art installation made from natural materials, inspiring us to create our own nature-inspired artwork right there on the trail.

meanings: Impunity means not being punished for something you did wrong, so you can act without worrying about getting in trouble.
examples: Some students believe they can cheat on tests with impunity, thinking that they won't get caught, but in reality, cheating can hurt their learning and future success.
During the history lesson, we learned that some leaders in the past acted with impunity, making decisions that harmed others without facing any consequences for their actions.
When kids bully others at school, they often feel they can do so with impunity, unaware of the emotional damage they cause and how it affects their classmates.
In video games, some players use hacks to win with impunity, but this not only ruins the experience for others but also goes against the spirit of fair play.
Scientists are working hard to protect endangered species from poachers who believe they can hunt with impunity, ignoring the laws that are meant to keep these animals safe.

meanings: Not alive; inanimate things, like rocks and chairs, don't move on their own or grow like living things do.
examples: In science class, we learned that rocks and minerals are inanimate objects, meaning they do not grow or breathe like living things do, which makes them fascinating subjects for our projects.
During our art project, we used inanimate materials like cardboard and plastic to create sculptures, allowing us to express our creativity without needing to rely on anything alive.
The museum displayed many inanimate artifacts from ancient civilizations, which helped us understand how people lived long ago, even though those objects have no life of their own.
