When we read about the history of ancient Rome, we discovered that some of the leaders used predatory tactics to expand their territories, often leading to conflicts with neighboring tribes and countries.
While playing our favorite video game, I realized that some characters are designed with predatory instincts, making them more challenging to defeat and adding excitement to our gaming experience.
During our nature hike, I was amazed to see a hawk soaring overhead, showcasing its predatory skills as it scanned the ground for unsuspecting prey beneath the trees.

meanings: The premiere is the very first time a movie, play, or show is shown to the public. It's like a big celebration where everyone gets to see it for the first time!
examples: The excitement in the auditorium was palpable as hundreds of students gathered to see the premiere of our school’s annual play, which showcased the incredible talents of our classmates.
After months of anticipation, I finally got to attend the premiere of my favorite video game, where players lined up to experience the latest adventures and challenges designed by the developers.
During art class, we learned about famous filmmakers, and I was inspired to create my own short film to showcase at the premiere during our school’s talent show next month.
My friends and I organized a movie night to celebrate the premiere of the highly anticipated sequel to our favorite adventure film, making popcorn and decorating the living room like a theater.
We were all thrilled when our science project was selected for the school fair, and we prepared for the premiere presentation that would allow us to share our findings with parents and teachers.

meanings: Something that is preposterous is so silly or unreasonable that it seems impossible, like suggesting that pigs can fly.
examples: It seemed preposterous to think that our science project could win first place when we barely had enough time to put it together, but our creativity surprised everyone, including ourselves.
During the history lesson, our teacher described a time when people believed in dragons, and I found it preposterous that anyone could actually think such creatures existed in real life.
When my friend suggested we could build a rocket out of soda bottles and fly to the moon, I couldn't help but laugh at how preposterous her idea sounded, even though I admired her imagination.
In the middle of our soccer game, one of my teammates claimed he could kick the ball all the way to the moon, and I thought that was a preposterous statement that made everyone burst into laughter.

As we watched the news about a giant inflatable hamster ball race, I realized how preposterous it was that people would actually participate in such a silly event, yet it made for entertaining viewing.

meanings: Trying to show off or seem more important than you really are, often by acting in a way that feels fake or over the top.
examples: During the art class, I found it frustrating when some students acted pretentious, pretending to be experts, while the rest of us just wanted to learn and share our creativity without feeling judged.

When he started using complicated words to explain simple ideas during our group project, it made him seem pretentious, as if he was trying too hard to impress everyone instead of just working together.
At the science fair, I was surprised to see how many projects looked amazing but were actually just pretentious displays, with flashy decorations instead of genuine scientific experiments and ideas.

While reading the latest fantasy novel, I noticed that some characters were portrayed as pretentious, always bragging about their wealth and talents, which made it hard to relate to them and enjoy the story.
During lunch, I overheard a group of kids talking in a pretentious manner about their expensive video games, making others feel left out and embarrassed for not being able to afford the same things.

meanings: The principal is the person in charge of a school who helps make important decisions and keeps everything running smoothly. They are like the captain of a team, guiding teachers and students to do their best.
examples: The principal announced a new recycling program at school, encouraging all students to participate in keeping our environment clean and sustainable for future generations, which made many of us excited to get involved.
After the basketball game, our principal congratulated the team for their hard work and dedication, reminding us that teamwork and sportsmanship are just as important as winning.
During the school assembly, the principal shared inspiring stories about famous scientists who changed the world, motivating us to explore our own interests in science and innovation.
When I visited the principal's office to discuss my ideas for a new club, I felt nervous but excited, knowing that my suggestions could help create a more engaging school environment.
At the end of the year, our principal held a special ceremony to celebrate the achievements of students, emphasizing the importance of perseverance and hard work in reaching our goals.

meanings: Prior" means something that happened before something else, like when you finish your homework before going out to play.
examples: Before starting our science project, we gathered information from books and articles to ensure we understood the prior research on the topic, which helped us form a solid hypothesis.
During the history lesson, the teacher explained how prior civilizations laid the groundwork for modern society, highlighting the importance of learning from the past to shape our future.
When planning our school play, we reviewed prior performances to see what worked well and what could be improved, allowing us to create a more engaging show for the audience.
As we prepared for our camping trip, my dad reminded us to check the weather forecast, since prior knowledge of conditions could help us pack the right gear and stay safe outdoors.
In our book club, we discussed how the main character's prior experiences influenced her decisions, making the story more relatable and showing how our own past can shape who we become.

meanings: A privilege is a special benefit or advantage that only some people get to enjoy, like having extra free time or being allowed to do something others can't.
examples: Having access to a good education is a privilege that many children around the world do not experience, making it important for us to appreciate our learning opportunities and help others gain the same advantages.
When we play on a sports team, it's a privilege to work together and support each other, as teamwork not only strengthens our friendships but also helps us grow as athletes.
In our community, having the privilege to volunteer at the local animal shelter allows us to learn about responsibility while making a positive impact on the lives of animals in need.
Reading books from the library is a privilege that opens up new worlds and ideas, encouraging us to explore different cultures and perspectives that enrich our understanding of the world.

As technology becomes more advanced, it’s a privilege for us to have access to the internet for research and learning, but we must also use it responsibly and think critically about the information we find.

meanings: To examine or look into something carefully to find out more information. It's like being a detective who tries to uncover clues about a mystery.
examples: During our science project, we decided to probe the effects of different types of soil on plant growth, carefully measuring how each plant responded to its environment over several weeks.
In history class, we learned about explorers who would probe uncharted territories, risking their safety to uncover new lands and cultures that had never been documented before.
As I read my favorite mystery book, I found myself wanting to probe deeper into the character's motivations, trying to understand what drove them to make such difficult choices.
When my friend and I decided to probe the local stream for interesting rocks and insects, we discovered a whole new world of tiny creatures that we had never noticed before.
In our debate club, we often probe complex social issues, asking tough questions and exploring various perspectives to better understand the challenges facing our community today.

meanings: To procure means to get something, usually by putting in some effort or making a special effort to find it. For example, you might procure a rare book by searching for it in different stores or online.
examples: To support our science project on renewable energy, we worked hard to procure all the necessary materials, including solar panels and batteries, so we could create a working model to demonstrate our ideas.
After weeks of searching online and visiting different stores, I finally managed to procure the rare comic book that my favorite superhero fans had been raving about, and I couldn’t wait to read it.
For our school's charity event, the student council decided to procure donations from local businesses, aiming to gather enough supplies to help families in need during the holiday season.
My dad and I planned a weekend trip to the mountains, and he promised to procure the hiking gear we needed, ensuring we were well-prepared for our adventure in nature.
During history class, we learned about how explorers had to procure their supplies and equipment through difficult journeys, which made me realize how much effort it took to discover new lands.

meanings: Being proficient means you are really good at doing something, like a sport or a school subject, because you've practiced and learned a lot about it.
examples: After months of practice, Jenna became proficient at playing the piano, impressing her music teacher with her ability to perform complex pieces effortlessly during the school recital.
In science class, we learned that astronauts must be proficient in various skills, such as piloting spacecraft and conducting experiments, to ensure their missions are successful and safe.
During basketball tryouts, Sam showed he was proficient at making three-point shots, which helped him secure a spot on the school team and become the star player this season.
As a proficient artist, Maria could capture the beauty of nature in her paintings, and her work was displayed at the local gallery, inspiring many of her classmates to explore their own creativity.
In our coding club, I became proficient at creating games using Python, which allowed me to share my projects with friends and even teach them how to code their own fun games.

meanings: Something that is expected to happen in the future or someone who is being considered for a particular job or role.
examples: The teacher invited several prospective students to visit our school, allowing them to see our classrooms, meet the staff, and learn about all the fun activities we have planned for the upcoming year.
As we prepared for the science fair, I felt excited about the prospective experiments we could showcase, and I was determined to create something that would impress both the judges and my classmates.

During the soccer tryouts, I noticed that the coach was watching the prospective players closely, evaluating our skills and teamwork to determine who would make it onto the final team roster for the season.
My parents discussed the prospective vacation destinations with me, and I couldn't help but imagine all the adventures we might have if we visited the mountains or the beach this summer.

In history class, we learned about the prospective outcomes of different events during the American Revolution, and it was fascinating to think about how our country might have turned out differently if certain choices had been made.

meanings: To lie flat on your stomach or back, often because you are very tired or feeling weak.
examples: After the long and exhausting soccer practice, I lay prostrate on the grass, staring up at the sky and thinking about how hard I had worked to improve my skills.
During the science experiment, the students were so focused on their task that they didn't notice when one of their classmates fell prostrate on the floor after getting dizzy from the chemicals.
When the dog chased the squirrel in the park, it ran so fast that it ended up prostrate on the ground, panting heavily and trying to catch its breath.
In the historical documentary we watched in class, the soldiers were shown lying prostrate on the battlefield, highlighting the sacrifices they made during the war for their country.
After the thrilling video game marathon, I felt so drained that I collapsed prostrate on my bedroom floor, ready for a much-needed break from the intense competition with my friends.

meanings: Prowess" means having great skill or talent in something, like playing a sport or mastering a musical instrument. It shows that someone is really good at what they do.
examples: During the science fair, Maria showcased her exceptional prowess in robotics by building a fully functioning robot that could solve puzzles and even dance, impressing both the judges and her classmates.
In basketball practice, Jake demonstrated his impressive prowess on the court, effortlessly sinking three-point shots while also helping his teammates improve their skills with encouraging advice.

The book club was amazed by Liam's prowess in storytelling, as he captivated everyone with his imaginative ideas and detailed descriptions that brought the characters to life during our weekly meetings.
At the regional chess tournament, Sarah displayed her strategic prowess by outsmarting her opponents with clever moves, ultimately leading her team to victory against tough competition.
During the school talent show, Emma wowed the audience with her singing prowess, hitting high notes with ease and leaving everyone cheering for an encore after her stunning performance.

meanings: Proximity means being close to something or someone, like when your friend lives nearby or when you're sitting next to someone in class.
examples: The scientists conducted an experiment to understand how plants grow best in different conditions, focusing on the proximity of sunlight and water sources to determine their overall health and growth rate.
During our field trip to the museum, I was amazed to see the proximity of ancient artifacts to modern technology, showcasing how much history can influence our current lives and innovations.
In our neighborhood, the proximity of the school to the library makes it easy for us to visit after class, allowing us to explore new books and work on our homework together.

While playing soccer at the park, I noticed that my teammates were always more successful in scoring goals when they maintained close proximity to one another, demonstrating the importance of teamwork in sports.
As we studied the effects of climate change in science class, we learned how the proximity of urban areas to natural habitats can impact wildlife and the environment in various ways.

meanings: A strong feeling of happiness and excitement, often when something wonderful happens, like receiving good news or enjoying a favorite activity.
examples: When the teacher announced that we would be going on a field trip to the science museum, my classmates and I erupted in rapture, eagerly discussing all the amazing exhibits we hoped to see.
As I opened the final chapter of my favorite book, a wave of rapture washed over me, knowing I was about to experience the thrilling conclusion of the story I had been immersed in for weeks.
Watching the sunset from the hilltop, surrounded by my friends, filled me with a sense of rapture as we shared our dreams and laughed at the beauty of the colorful sky.
When I scored the winning goal in our soccer game, I felt a rapture that was hard to describe; my teammates cheered, and my heart raced with joy and excitement.
After months of practice, the rapture I felt when I finally performed my song in the talent show was indescribable, especially when the audience erupted into applause at the end.

meanings: To realize something means to suddenly understand it or to notice it for the first time, like when you remember where you left your favorite toy.
examples: As I worked on my science project, I began to realize that the smallest changes in the environment can have a huge impact on the health of our planet.
While reading my favorite book series, I started to realize that the main character's struggles mirrored some of my own challenges in school and friendships, making the story even more relatable.
During our history lesson, I began to realize how important it is to learn from past events so that we can make better choices for our future and avoid repeating the same mistakes.
When I practiced soccer with my teammates, I could finally realize that teamwork and communication are just as vital as individual skills in achieving our goals on the field.
While volunteering at the animal shelter, I started to realize how many pets need loving homes, which inspired me to raise awareness in my community about the importance of adoption.

meanings: To move back or go away from something, like when the water in a wave pulls back from the shore.
examples: As the tide began to recede, we explored the rocky shore, discovering fascinating shells and small sea creatures that had been hidden beneath the water's surface.
During the science experiment, we observed how the water level in the container would recede after the sand absorbed it, demonstrating the effects of erosion in a fun and interactive way.
After the storm passed, the clouds slowly began to recede, revealing a stunning rainbow that stretched across the sky, reminding us of nature's beauty after a turbulent event.
When I practiced my basketball skills, I noticed that my confidence would recede whenever I missed a shot, but I learned that perseverance and practice could help me improve.
As we read the chapter in our history book, we discussed how the ancient civilizations would recede into the background of time, leaving behind only ruins and stories for us to uncover.

meanings: Ready and willing to listen to new ideas or suggestions; open-minded.
examples: During our science class, the teacher encouraged us to be receptive to different ideas about climate change, helping us understand the importance of listening to various perspectives to find solutions.
When I presented my new video game design concept to my classmates, I was pleasantly surprised by how receptive they were, offering constructive feedback that helped me improve my project.
While reading a book about famous inventors, I realized that being receptive to others' ideas can lead to groundbreaking innovations that change the world for the better.
In our group project, I noticed that my teammates were very receptive to each other's suggestions, which made it easier for us to create a presentation that showcased everyone's strengths.
As we discussed current events in class, it was inspiring to see how receptive my classmates were to learning about different cultures and social issues that affect our world today.

meanings: To renovate means to fix up a building or a room to make it look new and nice again. This can include painting walls, replacing old furniture, or repairing broken things.
examples: This summer, my family decided to renovate our backyard by adding a new garden and building a small play area for my little brother, making it a perfect place for us to relax and have fun together.

After learning about the importance of preserving history, our class worked on a project to renovate an old school building, creating a museum that showcases our town’s rich past and teaches others about its significance.
When my parents bought an old house, they planned to renovate it by restoring the original woodwork and updating the kitchen, so it would be both beautiful and functional for our family.
As part of our science fair project, my friend and I decided to renovate a neglected community park by cleaning it up and planting flowers, hoping to inspire others to take care of our environment.

While reading about ancient civilizations, I was fascinated to learn how archaeologists renovate ruins to help us understand how people lived thousands of years ago, bringing history back to life for everyone to see.

meanings: To refill or restore something that has been used up, like putting more juice in a glass after drinking it.
examples: After the soccer game, our coach reminded us to drink water to replenish our bodies and stay hydrated, especially since we played so hard in the hot sun.
In science class, we learned how trees help to replenish the air with oxygen, making our environment healthier for all living creatures, including us!
When we go on family hikes, my parents always bring extra snacks to replenish our energy, so we can keep exploring and enjoying the beauty of nature without feeling tired.
During our art project, we realized we needed to replenish our supply of paint, so we made a list and headed to the store to restock our favorite colors.
After the school year ended, the local library held a summer reading program to help students replenish their love for books and encourage them to explore new genres and stories.

meanings: To reprimand someone means to tell them they did something wrong, often in a serious way, like when a teacher talks to a student about not following the rules.
examples: After the soccer match, the coach decided to reprimand the player for arguing with the referee, explaining that respect is essential in both sports and life.
When I forgot to turn in my homework, my teacher gave me a gentle reprimand and reminded me about the importance of responsibility in our studies.
During the group project, Sarah received a reprimand from our teacher for not collaborating with her teammates, which taught us all the value of working together effectively.
My parents chose to reprimand me when they discovered I had stayed up too late playing video games, emphasizing the need for a balanced routine and proper sleep.
In history class, the teacher had to reprimand a few students for talking too much during the lesson, reminding us that listening is just as important as participating in discussions.

meanings: To refuse to accept or agree with something, like when you decide not to believe in a rumor or not to support a plan you think is wrong.
examples: When the teacher presented a new rule that seemed unfair to the students, many of us decided to repudiate it by writing a letter to the principal explaining our concerns and suggesting a better solution.
After discovering that the online game was filled with cheating players, I chose to repudiate my membership and find a different game that focused on fair play and teamwork instead.
In history class, we learned about leaders who chose to repudiate injustice, standing up for their beliefs even when it was difficult and dangerous to do so, inspiring others to follow their example.
When my friend tried to convince me to skip class for a day of fun, I had to repudiate the idea firmly, reminding him that our education was important for our future.
While reading a book about environmental issues, I found it powerful how the author encouraged readers to repudiate pollution by taking small actions in their daily lives to protect our planet.

meanings: To find a solution to a problem or make a strong decision about what to do next. For example, when you resolve a conflict with a friend, you figure out how to fix the disagreement.
examples: After hours of discussion, the student council finally decided to resolve the issue of school lunches by proposing healthier options that everyone could enjoy, ensuring all voices were heard in the process.
When the two friends had a disagreement about which video game to play, they took a moment to cool off before coming together to resolve their conflict by finding a game they both liked.
The science project was challenging, but after brainstorming together, the team was able to resolve their differences and create a fantastic presentation that impressed their teacher and classmates.
As the soccer coach, I encouraged the players to resolve their differences on the field by communicating better and working together, which ultimately led to a more successful game.
While reading the book, I admired how the main character managed to resolve her fears by facing them head-on, which taught me the importance of courage in challenging situations.

meanings: A respite is a short break or pause from something hard or annoying, like taking a moment to relax during a tough homework session.
examples: After studying for hours for the science test, I took a short respite by playing my favorite video game, which helped clear my mind and recharge my energy.
During the long hike up the mountain, we paused for a brief respite at a scenic overlook, where we enjoyed a snack and admired the breathtaking view below.
After a busy week filled with homework and soccer practice, I found a much-needed respite in reading my favorite book, allowing me to escape into another world for a little while.
While working on our group project, we decided to take a short respite and play a quick game of charades, which lifted our spirits and made us more focused afterward.
The community center organized a fun day at the park, providing a respite for families facing tough times, where everyone could enjoy games, food, and each other’s company.

meanings: To respond to someone quickly, often in a clever or funny way, especially during a conversation or argument.
examples: When Sarah teased Mark about his new haircut, he quickly came up with a clever retort, saying that at least his hair was easier to manage than her messy bun.
During the debate in social studies class, Jenna prepared a strong argument, but when her opponent made a silly remark, she couldn't resist giving a witty retort that made the whole class laugh.
As the coach called for a team meeting, Jake made a funny comment about his lack of athletic skills, to which his teammate Sam shot back with a playful retort that boosted everyone's spirits.
In the middle of a science discussion about climate change, Mia offered a thoughtful retort when someone dismissed the topic, explaining why it was essential for their generation to take action now.
When I complained about the homework being too difficult, my sister had a quick retort, reminding me that math is just like a video game: the more you practice, the better you get!

meanings: Revelry means having a lot of fun at a lively party or celebration, where people are often singing, dancing, and enjoying themselves together.
examples: The annual school carnival was filled with revelry, as students laughed and cheered while enjoying games, delicious food, and exciting rides that made the night unforgettable.
During the history project, our group decided to recreate a medieval festival, complete with costumes and music, which turned our classroom into a scene of revelry that everyone enjoyed.
After winning the championship game, our soccer team celebrated with revelry, dancing and singing together on the field, feeling proud of our hard work and teamwork throughout the season.
The neighborhood block party brought everyone together for an evening of revelry, where families shared their favorite dishes and children played games until the stars lit up the sky.

As we gathered around the campfire during our summer camping trip, the revelry of storytelling and roasting marshmallows created lasting memories and deepened our friendships under the twinkling stars.

meanings: Robust means strong and healthy, able to handle tough situations without breaking down, like a sturdy tree that can survive strong winds and storms.
examples: The robust tree in the backyard has survived many storms, standing tall and strong, which inspires me to be resilient in the face of challenges at school and in life.
During our science project, we learned that a robust ecosystem can support a wide variety of plants and animals, showing us the importance of protecting our environment for future generations.
In basketball practice, my coach emphasized the need for a robust training regimen to help us build strength and endurance, which is essential for performing well during the championship games.
The robust friendship between the two characters in the book taught me that true friends support each other through difficult times, reminding me to be there for my friends when they need me most.

Our school's robust debate club encourages students to express their opinions confidently and respectfully, fostering critical thinking skills that will help us in our future careers and civic responsibilities.

meanings: To suddenly break apart or burst, like when a balloon pops or a pipe leaks, causing things to separate or leak out.
examples: During the science experiment, a sudden rupture of the balloon caused everyone in the classroom to jump in surprise, but it also sparked a lively discussion about air pressure and gases.
While hiking in the mountains, the geologist explained that the rupture of a rock layer can lead to landslides, which is why it's important to be cautious in steep areas.
In our history class, we learned how the rupture of the Berlin Wall in 1989 symbolized the end of division in Germany, allowing families to reunite and celebrate their freedom together.
After a tense game of soccer, the referee had to stop play when a player suffered a rupture in his ankle, reminding us all how important it is to warm up properly before a match.
When a friendship starts to rupture due to misunderstandings, it's essential to communicate openly and try to resolve the issues before they become too big to handle.

meanings: Rustic" means something that is simple and natural, often related to the countryside, like a cozy cabin or handmade furniture that feels warm and inviting.
examples: The rustic cabin in the woods was the perfect getaway for our family, allowing us to disconnect from technology and enjoy nature's beauty while roasting marshmallows by the campfire.
During our history project, we learned about rustic farming techniques that early settlers used, which helped them grow their own food and build a strong community in the countryside.
As we walked through the local farmers' market, I admired the rustic wooden stands filled with fresh fruits and vegetables, and it made me appreciate how much effort goes into producing our food.
In art class, we created paintings inspired by rustic landscapes, using earthy colors and simple designs to capture the charm of the countryside and remind us of peaceful moments spent outdoors.
My grandparents' rustic home, with its old-fashioned furniture and handmade decorations, tells stories of their life on a farm, giving me a deeper understanding of my family's history and traditions.

meanings: Being ruthless means being very cruel or harsh, without caring about how others feel. It’s when someone does not show kindness or compassion, even when they should.
examples: In the competitive world of video games, some players can be ruthless, using every trick in the book to win, even if it means making their friends feel bad or left out in the process.

During the intense basketball game, the opposing team played with such ruthless determination that it was clear they would stop at nothing to secure their victory, leaving us feeling overwhelmed and discouraged.

In the history project, my classmates and I learned about a ruthless ruler who made harsh decisions that affected the lives of many people, showing us how power can sometimes lead to cruelty and injustice.

As we read the novel about a ruthless villain, I couldn’t help but think about how their lack of compassion created so many problems for the characters, teaching us the importance of kindness and empathy.
Even though the animal documentary showed the ruthless behavior of predators in the wild, it reminded us that nature has a delicate balance and every creature plays a role in the ecosystem.

meanings: Something that is sacred is considered very special and important, often because it is connected to religion or deep beliefs. People treat sacred things with great respect and care, like how some people feel about places of worship or certain rituals.
examples: Many cultures around the world have sacred traditions, where specific rituals or ceremonies are performed to honor their beliefs and connect with their history and ancestors.
In science class, we learned about the sacred balance of ecosystems, which emphasizes how every plant and animal plays an important role in maintaining a healthy environment.

During our history lesson, we discovered that ancient civilizations often built sacred temples to worship their gods, reflecting their deep respect for the forces of nature they believed controlled their lives.
When I visited the national park, I felt a sacred connection to the land and its wildlife, reminding me of the importance of preserving nature for future generations to enjoy.
In literature, many heroes embark on sacred quests, where they not only seek treasure or adventure but also strive to uphold values like bravery, friendship, and loyalty in their journeys.

meanings: To give up something important or valuable, like time or belongings, to help someone else or to achieve a better goal.
examples: During the science fair, I had to sacrifice my free time for several weeks to prepare my project, but in the end, the hard work paid off when I won first place.
To help my team win the championship, I decided to sacrifice my individual goals and play a different position that better supported my teammates' strengths.
When my best friend moved away, I had to sacrifice our weekend hangouts, but we promised to stay connected through video calls and letters, keeping our friendship strong.
In the book I read, the hero had to make a difficult sacrifice, giving up his own safety to protect his friends from danger, which taught me the true meaning of bravery.
My parents often remind me that to succeed in life, sometimes we must sacrifice short-term pleasures, like playing video games, for long-term goals like studying for important exams.

meanings: Not having enough of something; when there is a small amount that isn't sufficient to meet needs or expectations.
examples: The scientist noted that the data from the experiment was scanty, which made it difficult to draw any meaningful conclusions about the effects of the new chemical compound.
During our history project, we discovered that the scanty records from the ancient civilization made it challenging to understand their culture and daily life.
After the rainstorm, the garden looked beautiful, but the scanty blooms reminded us that we needed to take better care of our plants to help them thrive.
While preparing for the big soccer match, I realized our team's practice time was scanty, which worried me about whether we would perform our best against the stronger opponents.
The book we were reading in class had only a scanty amount of information about the main character's background, leaving us curious about their past and motivations.

meanings: To search through trash or leftover food to find something useful or edible.
examples: During our science project, we decided to scavenge for materials in the recycling bin to create a model of a sustainable city, which turned out to be both fun and educational.
On our nature hike, we learned how animals scavenge for food, using their keen senses to find leftovers from other creatures, which helps keep the ecosystem balanced.
After the big storm, we ventured outside to scavenge for fallen branches and leaves, turning our findings into a creative art project that showcased the beauty of nature's leftovers.
In history class, we discovered how ancient civilizations had to scavenge for resources, often relying on what was left behind by others to survive and thrive in their environments.
When we play video games, my character often has to scavenge for supplies in abandoned buildings, teaching me the importance of resourcefulness in challenging situations.

meanings: Very careful about doing the right thing and making sure everything is fair and honest.
examples: The scrupulous student double-checked her math homework to ensure that every answer was correct before turning it in, knowing that even a small mistake could affect her grade.
As a scrupulous member of the school newspaper, he always fact-checked his articles to make sure that the information was accurate and fair, which earned him the respect of his peers.

During the science project, the scrupulous group made sure to follow all safety guidelines and conduct their experiments ethically, demonstrating their commitment to responsibility and careful research.

When organizing the charity event, the scrupulous volunteers carefully planned every detail, from how to allocate funds to how to treat all participants with respect, ensuring a successful and enjoyable experience for everyone.
In history class, the scrupulous teacher emphasized the importance of citing sources correctly, so her students would understand how to give credit to the original authors and avoid plagiarism.

meanings: A sham is something that looks real or true but is actually fake or a trick. It's like pretending to be something you’re not, like wearing a costume that makes you look like a superhero but isn't really one.
examples: The advertisement for the new video game seemed exciting, but after playing it, I realized it was a complete sham, offering nothing more than flashy graphics and no real gameplay.
During our history project, we discovered that the famous treasure map was a sham, created to trick adventurers into searching for something that never existed.
When the school announced a “perfect attendance” award, many students felt it was a sham because it didn’t consider the days we missed for legitimate reasons like illness or family emergencies.

After researching different charities, I learned that some organizations advertised themselves as helping the needy, but they were actually a sham, using donations for personal gain instead of helping others.
In our science class, we discussed how some products labeled as "natural" can be a sham, containing hidden chemicals that can be harmful to our health and the environment.

meanings: To show or mean something, often by using a sign, symbol, or action that helps others understand your message.
examples: The colors of the leaves changing in autumn signify that winter is approaching, reminding us to prepare for the colder months ahead and to appreciate the beauty of nature's transformations.
In literature, a character’s change in behavior often signifies their growth and development, teaching readers valuable lessons about friendship and personal challenges they may face in life.
During our science experiment, the bubbling reaction in the test tube began to signify that the mixture was reacting correctly, which made everyone excited to see the results of our hard work.

When the teacher clapped her hands and smiled, it seemed to signify that we had done a great job on our group project, boosting our confidence and encouraging us to take on more challenges in the future.

In video games, collecting certain items can signify that a player has reached a new level or unlocked special abilities, making the game more exciting and motivating players to continue their adventure.

meanings: Slaughter means to kill animals for food, like when meat is prepared for meals, or it can refer to the violent killing of many people.
examples: In history class, we learned about how the slaughter of innocent animals for food has sparked debates about animal rights and the importance of treating all living creatures with kindness and respect.

The documentary we watched in science class revealed the shocking statistics about the slaughter of endangered species, highlighting the urgent need for conservation efforts to protect our planet's biodiversity.

During our discussion on World War II, we examined how the slaughter of countless soldiers and civilians affected families across the globe, reminding us of the importance of peace and understanding among nations.
As we explored the themes in the novel, it became clear that the slaughter of the protagonist's village served as a powerful metaphor for the loss of innocence and the harsh realities of war.

At the local farm, we learned about the process of livestock management, including the ethical considerations surrounding the slaughter of animals for food, which led to a thoughtful conversation about our choices as consumers.

meanings: Sleek" means having a smooth and shiny surface that looks nice, like a well-groomed pet or a stylish car. It can also describe something that is designed to be attractive and modern.
examples: The new electric car in our science class project had a sleek design, with smooth lines and a shiny finish that impressed everyone during the presentation.
At the art exhibit, I was captivated by the sleek sculptures that seemed to flow effortlessly, making the entire gallery feel modern and inviting.
My older brother just got a sleek new gaming console, and its glossy surface and advanced features make it the envy of all his friends whenever they come over to play.
As I walked through the park, I noticed the sleek ducks gliding effortlessly across the pond, their feathers glimmering in the sunlight, creating a beautiful scene in nature.
The latest smartphone model has a sleek appearance that combines cutting-edge technology with a stylish design, making it a popular choice among kids and adults alike.

meanings: To burn slowly without flames, creating smoke and heat, like when a campfire is dying down.
examples: After the campfire had burned out, I noticed the logs continued to smolder, sending up wisps of smoke that reminded me of the stories my grandfather tells about his adventures in the forest.
In science class, we learned that when a fire smolders, it can produce harmful smoke without any visible flames, which is why it's important to be careful when we start a fire for camping.
As the sun set over the horizon, the embers from our bonfire began to smolder, creating a warm glow that made us feel cozy while we shared our favorite ghost stories.
The old, abandoned house in our neighborhood seemed to smolder in the twilight, with smoke curling from the chimney, leading us to wonder if anyone still lived there or if it was truly forgotten.

During our history lesson, we discussed how ancient civilizations used smoldering fires to create tools from metal, which sparked my curiosity about how they managed to innovate without modern technology.

meanings: Solitude is the state of being alone, usually by choice, where you can think, relax, or enjoy your own company without distractions.
examples: After a long week of school and activities, I often find peace in solitude, sitting in my favorite spot in the garden where I can read and think without any distractions.
During the summer, I cherish moments of solitude while hiking in the mountains, where the only sounds are the rustling leaves and the gentle whisper of the wind through the trees.
My art teacher encouraged us to embrace solitude as a way to find inspiration, suggesting that spending time alone can help us discover our true creative selves.
While some kids enjoy being in large groups, I prefer the solitude of my room, where I can play video games and immerse myself in different worlds without any interruptions.
In the book we’re reading for class, the main character experiences solitude after moving to a new town, and it teaches her valuable lessons about friendship and finding her own voice.

meanings: A sovereign is a king, queen, or leader who has the highest power in a country and makes important decisions for the people.
examples: In history class, we learned that a sovereign could be a king or queen who has the final say on important decisions affecting their kingdom, just like how our school principal makes rules that everyone must follow.

During our social studies project, we discussed how a sovereign nation has the power to govern itself without interference from other countries, similar to how my family makes choices about our own home.
In the fantasy book I’m reading, the brave hero must protect his sovereign from an evil sorcerer, showing how important it is to defend the leader of one’s land against threats.
As we studied the different forms of government, I realized that a sovereign democracy allows citizens to vote for their leaders, much like how we vote for class representatives in school.

While playing my favorite video game, I noticed that the sovereign of the virtual kingdom I was trying to save had to make tough choices to keep peace among rival factions, just like in real-life leadership situations.

meanings: A species is a group of living things that are very similar and can have babies together, like dogs or cats. Each species has its own unique traits that make it different from other groups.
examples: In our science class, we learned that there are over 8.7 million different species on Earth, each adapted to its environment in unique and fascinating ways.
While hiking in the forest, we spotted a rare species of bird that only lives in that region, reminding us of the importance of protecting natural habitats for all living creatures.
As we researched endangered species for our school project, we discovered that many animals are at risk due to habitat loss and climate change, which affects their ability to survive and reproduce.
My favorite book series features a magical species of creatures that can shape-shift, teaching me about the importance of diversity and accepting differences in the world around us.
During our visit to the aquarium, we learned that some fish species can change color to blend into their surroundings, which helps them avoid predators in their underwater habitats.

meanings: A sphere is a perfectly round three-dimensional shape, like a basketball or a globe, where every point on its surface is the same distance from the center.
examples: In science class, we learned that the Earth is not a perfect sphere, but rather an oblate spheroid, which means it’s slightly flattened at the poles and bulging at the equator.
When I was playing basketball with my friends, I noticed how the ball is a perfect sphere, allowing it to roll smoothly and bounce evenly when it hits the ground.
During our art project, we created sculptures using clay, and I decided to make a beautiful sphere that represented the planet, complete with painted continents and oceans.
In geometry, we studied different shapes, and I found it fascinating that a sphere has no edges or corners, making it a unique and elegant three-dimensional figure.
While reading a science fiction book, I was intrigued by the idea of a space station designed like a giant sphere, where astronauts could live and work in a zero-gravity environment.

meanings: To spurn means to reject or refuse something in a way that shows you think it's not good or important. For example, if someone offers you something you really don't want, you might spurn it by saying no with a look of disgust.
examples: After much thought, Jenna decided to spurn the invitation to the party because she knew it would distract her from studying for the important math test coming up next week.
When the coach offered him a chance to try out for the basketball team, Kyle chose to spurn the opportunity, believing he needed to focus more on his art projects instead.
Despite her friends urging her to play video games all weekend, Mia chose to spurn their offers, preferring to spend her time reading the latest fantasy novel she had been excited about.
During the science fair, Jason's classmates were impressed by his project, but he decided to spurn their praise, feeling that he could have done much better with more time and effort.
When presented with the chance to join a new club at school, Sam was tempted but ultimately chose to spurn it, knowing he wanted to dedicate more time to his soccer practice and improve his skills.

meanings: Staunch means being very loyal and dedicated to a person or cause, like a best friend who always stands by you no matter what.
examples: My staunch support for the school's environmental club motivated my friends to join, and together we organized a campaign to reduce plastic use in our cafeteria.
During the history project, my staunch belief in teamwork encouraged everyone to contribute their ideas, resulting in a fantastic presentation that impressed our teacher.
Even when the team faced challenging opponents, my staunch determination helped keep my friends' spirits high, reminding them that we could still improve and have fun together.
I have a staunch commitment to reading every book in my favorite series, and I often share my thoughts with my classmates to inspire them to discover new stories.
After witnessing a classmate being bullied, I felt a staunch responsibility to stand up for what is right, and I reported the incident to ensure our school remains a safe place for everyone.

meanings: A stint is a specific amount of time you spend doing a job or activity, like when you help out at a school event for a few hours or work on a project for a few weeks.
examples: After completing her stint as the class president, Maria felt proud of the positive changes she had made in the school and was excited to see her friends continue her work.
During our science project, we agreed to each take a stint in the lab, so everyone would have a chance to explore and contribute their ideas to the group's final presentation.
My brother decided to take a short stint volunteering at the animal shelter, and he discovered a new passion for helping animals find loving homes.
After a two-week stint at summer camp, I returned home with new friends, unforgettable memories, and a strong desire to improve my skills in archery.
When my teacher assigned us a stint of reading each night, I discovered that I actually enjoyed diving into new worlds through the pages of different books.

meanings: A strait is a narrow area of water that connects two larger seas or oceans, like a bridge made of water. It's important for ships because it helps them travel between different parts of the ocean.
examples: As we studied maps in social studies class, I learned that the strait between the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans is crucial for international shipping and trade routes around the world.
During our science project on ecosystems, we discovered that the strait near our coast is home to many unique marine species, making it an important area for biodiversity and conservation efforts.

My grandfather shared fascinating stories about how explorers navigated through the strait to discover new lands, which inspired me to learn more about maritime history and the adventures of those brave sailors.
While sailing with my family, we crossed a narrow strait that connected two beautiful islands, and I felt excited to see how the water changed colors as we moved from one side to the other.
In our geography club, we discussed the importance of the strait in allowing different cultures to interact and share ideas, which has shaped the world we live in today.

meanings: Involving a lot of hard work and energy, like running a long race or carrying something heavy.
examples: Running a marathon is a strenuous activity that tests both the physical endurance and mental strength of the participants, pushing them to their limits as they strive to cross the finish line.

During our science project, we discovered that building a model volcano required strenuous effort, as we had to gather materials, create the structure, and ensure it would erupt perfectly for our presentation.

While training for the school basketball team, I found that the strenuous drills helped improve my skills, but they also made me appreciate the importance of teamwork and perseverance in achieving our goals.
After spending a strenuous day hiking up the steep mountain trail, my friends and I were exhausted but thrilled to finally reach the breathtaking viewpoint overlooking the valley below.
Completing a complex puzzle can be a strenuous challenge, especially when working as a team, but the sense of accomplishment we felt when we finished it together was well worth the effort.

meanings: Very strict and demanding about following rules or standards, like a teacher who expects everyone to do their best work without cutting corners.
examples: The school's new policy on homework is quite stringent, requiring students to complete every assignment with no exceptions, which has made many of us feel stressed about our grades.
In science class, our teacher explained that the stringent safety rules in the laboratory are vital to prevent accidents and ensure everyone goes home safely at the end of the day.
During basketball practice, our coach enforced stringent rules about teamwork and communication, believing that following these guidelines would help us play better together during the big game.
While volunteering at the animal shelter, I learned that there are stringent regulations in place to protect the animals and ensure they receive proper care and a safe environment.
The stringent guidelines for the science fair projects encouraged us to think critically and conduct thorough research, pushing us to create our best work yet.

meanings: To go completely under the water, like when you dive into a pool or when something sinks below the surface.
examples: During our science experiment, we had to submerge the small plastic boat in a tank of water to see how the different weights affected its ability to float.
As I read my favorite adventure book, I felt as if I could submerge myself in the story and explore the magical world alongside the brave characters.
When we went to the beach, my friends and I decided to submerge ourselves in the waves, laughing and splashing as we tried to catch the surfboards riding on the water.

The artist created a stunning mural that seemed to submerge the viewer in a vibrant underwater scene filled with colorful fish and swirling seaweed, making everyone feel like they were diving into the ocean.
In history class, we learned how ancient civilizations would often submerge their offerings in rivers, believing this would please the gods and bring good fortune to their communities.

meanings: To become weaker or less intense; for something like noise, excitement, or pain to lessen over time.
examples: After the storm passed, the fierce winds began to subside, allowing us to venture outside and assess the damage to our neighborhood's trees and fences.
During our science experiment, we watched as the bubbles in the fizzy drink started to subside, revealing the colorful layers of liquid beneath the surface.
When my little brother gets upset over losing a game, I try to comfort him until his tears subside, reminding him that it's all about having fun and trying your best.
As the excitement of the championship game began to subside, the players shook hands and congratulated each other, showing good sportsmanship and respect for their opponents.
After a few minutes of silence following the surprising announcement, the initial shock in the classroom began to subside, and we all started discussing how it would affect our school year.

meanings: Subtle means something that is not easy to notice or see right away, like a quiet hint or a small change that requires careful attention to understand.
examples: The artist used subtle shades of blue and green in her painting, which made the scene of the ocean feel calm and peaceful without being too loud or overwhelming.
As we studied the behavior of different animals in science class, we noticed the subtle ways they communicated with each other, like the soft gestures of a cat when it wants attention.

During the group project, my friend made a subtle suggestion that improved our presentation, showing us how important it is to listen carefully to everyone's ideas, even when they are not immediately obvious.
While reading the novel, I discovered the author's subtle hints about the main character's feelings, which added depth to the story and made me think more about what she was experiencing.
In soccer practice, my coach pointed out the subtle movements that could help us outsmart our opponents, teaching us that sometimes small changes can lead to big victories on the field.

meanings: To supervise means to watch over and guide people as they work or do activities, making sure they are doing things correctly and safely.
examples: During the school science fair, our teacher decided to supervise each project carefully to ensure that all the students followed safety rules and understood the experiments they were conducting.
As the team captain, I had to supervise my teammates during practice to make sure everyone was following the drills and improving their basketball skills before the big game this weekend.
My parents asked me to supervise my younger siblings while they played outside, reminding me to keep an eye on them to ensure they stayed safe and didn’t wander too far from home.
In our art class, the instructor would often supervise us closely as we worked on our paintings, providing valuable feedback and encouragement to help us express our creativity more effectively.

When organizing the school talent show, a group of students was chosen to supervise the performers backstage, ensuring they were ready to go on stage and supporting them with any last-minute preparations.

meanings: Something that is tedious feels very boring and takes a long time, especially because it involves doing the same thing over and over again, like doing homework that seems never-ending.
examples: Studying for the math test felt tedious as I had to solve the same types of problems over and over again, but I knew it was important to practice in order to do well.
While the documentary about ancient civilizations was fascinating, some parts were so tedious that I found myself daydreaming instead of paying attention to the rich details.
My little brother thinks organizing his toy collection is tedious, but I find it satisfying to see everything neatly arranged, making it easier to find his favorite action figures.
Completing the long science project was tedious because it required so much research and writing, but I felt proud when I finally saw the finished poster on display.
Even though the book we had to read for class was a bit tedious at times, I discovered some interesting facts about history that sparked my curiosity to learn more.

meanings: A theme is the main idea or message in a story, movie, or discussion that helps us understand what it’s really about, like friendship, bravery, or growing up.
examples: The theme of friendship is central to many of the stories we read in class, illustrating how bonds can help us overcome challenges and support each other through difficult times.
In our science project, we focused on the theme of environmental conservation, highlighting how important it is to protect our planet and the creatures that live on it for future generations.
During the history lesson, the theme of courage emerged as we learned about famous figures who stood up for their beliefs, inspiring us to think about how we can be brave in our own lives.
As we played the new video game together, we discussed the theme of teamwork, realizing that cooperating and communicating effectively can lead to better results and more fun for everyone involved.
In the book we are reading, the theme of discovery resonates deeply, encouraging us to explore our own interests and passions while also learning to appreciate the world around us.

meanings: A throng is a large crowd of people who are closely packed together, like when you see a big group at a concert or a parade.
examples: As the final bell rang, a throng of students poured out of the school, excitedly chattering about the weekend plans and the latest video game releases.
During the historical reenactment, a throng of visitors gathered around the performers, eager to witness the battles and learn more about life in the 18th century.
At the annual science fair, a throng of curious parents and students moved from table to table, marveling at the innovative projects and experiments displayed by the young scientists.
When the concert started, the throng of fans cheered loudly, their enthusiasm filling the air with energy as they sang along to their favorite songs.
While hiking through the national park, we encountered a throng of fellow nature lovers, all eager to capture the stunning views and share their experiences with one another.

meanings: To work very hard for a long time, usually doing something that takes a lot of effort and can be tiring.
examples: After weeks of toil in the garden, planting seeds and pulling weeds, I was thrilled to see vibrant flowers blooming all around my backyard.
During the science fair, my classmates and I had to toil late into the night to ensure our projects were perfect, and our hard work paid off with several awards.
The young athletes toiled every afternoon at practice, pushing themselves to improve their skills, knowing that their dedication would lead to success during the championship game.
In history class, we learned about the pioneers who toiled across the country, facing harsh conditions and challenges, yet their determination helped shape the nation we live in today.
As I sat by the computer, I could feel the toil of studying for my math test weighing on me, but I knew that understanding the material would make a big difference in my grade.

meanings: Toxic means something that can harm living things, like plants and animals, often because it contains poison or dangerous chemicals. For example, certain plants or chemicals can make you sick if you touch or eat them.
examples: Some plants in our garden can be toxic if eaten, so it's important to learn which ones are safe before we pick and taste any of the fruits or vegetables.
During our science class, we discovered how certain chemicals can be toxic to the environment, harming wildlife and plants, which made us think about how we can help protect nature.
When discussing the effects of bullying, we learned that toxic friendships can be just as harmful as toxic substances, affecting our mental health and self-esteem in negative ways.

In history class, we studied how some ancient civilizations faced challenges due to toxic waste from their industries, leading to environmental disasters that impacted their communities for generations.
While playing video games, we realized that some online behaviors can be toxic, creating a negative atmosphere that makes it hard for everyone to enjoy the game and have fun together.

meanings: A trek is a long and often challenging journey you take on foot, usually through nature, like hiking in the mountains or walking through a forest.
examples: As we prepared for our weekend camping trip, my friends and I excitedly planned our trek through the dense forest, eager to explore the beauty of nature and discover hidden trails.
During our history project, we learned about the incredible trek made by early explorers who faced dangerous conditions and unknown territories in their quest to map the uncharted lands.
After school, my brother and I decided to embark on a trek around our neighborhood, hoping to find interesting landmarks and take pictures for our geography project.
The documentary we watched in class described the amazing trek of climbers reaching the summit of Mount Everest, showcasing their determination and teamwork in overcoming extreme challenges.
While reading our favorite adventure book, I imagined myself joining the main character on a thrilling trek across the mountains, facing fierce storms and discovering ancient secrets along the way.

meanings: Something that is trifling is not very important or valuable; it's like a small problem that doesn't really matter in the big picture.
examples: During our group project, I realized that arguing over the color of our poster was trifling, as we should have focused on the research instead.
While studying for the big math test, I found that worrying about trifling details, like which pencil to use, only distracted me from the important concepts I needed to master.
As we played our favorite video game, I noticed that getting upset over a trifling mistake, like missing a jump, only made the game less enjoyable for everyone.
In our science class, we learned that spending too much time on trifling experiments could keep us from exploring the more exciting and significant topics in the curriculum.
When discussing the latest movie, I realized that focusing on trifling aspects, like a character's outfit, distracted us from the deeper themes and messages that really mattered.

meanings: The ultimate means the best or most important version of something, like the final level in a video game that is the hardest to beat. It can also refer to the last step in a series of actions.
examples: The ultimate goal of our science project is to create a sustainable energy model that not only impresses our teachers but also inspires our classmates to think about environmental issues in a new way.

In the thrilling final match of the soccer tournament, our team worked hard together, knowing that winning would be the ultimate achievement of our season and a testament to our dedication and teamwork.
As I read the last chapter of the book, I realized that the ultimate lesson the author wanted to teach us was about the importance of friendship and loyalty in overcoming life's challenges.
During our history class, we learned that the ultimate decision made by leaders during the war changed the course of our nation and shaped the world we live in today.
With each level I complete in the video game, I aim for the ultimate prize, which not only unlocks new challenges but also gives me bragging rights among my friends.

meanings: Moving in a way that looks awkward or clumsy, like when someone trips or has trouble balancing.
examples: As the giraffe moved through the crowded zoo, its ungainly legs seemed to tangle with each other, making it look both fascinating and a bit silly to the delighted visitors.
During gym class, I tried to master the new dance routine, but I felt ungainly and out of sync with my friends, which made me laugh at my own awkwardness.
When I attempted to ride my new skateboard for the first time, my ungainly balance sent me tumbling into the grass, but I quickly got back up, determined to try again.
The science experiment involved creating a model of a volcano, and while my creation was impressive, it turned out ungainly and top-heavy, making it difficult to transport to the school display.
As we played soccer on the field, my teammate's ungainly attempts to kick the ball often resulted in hilarious misses that kept everyone laughing, even though he was trying his hardest.

meanings: Not hurt or damaged; staying safe after a difficult situation, like coming through a storm without any injuries.
examples: After the intense storm passed through our town, we were relieved to find that our house remained unscathed, while many of our neighbors faced damage to their roofs and fences.

During the science experiment, we were amazed to see that the fragile egg we carefully placed in the protective container emerged unscathed, proving that our design was effective in preventing any breaks.
When the school organized an outdoor field day, everyone was thrilled to see that the students playing games in the mud came out unscathed, even though they were covered in dirt and laughter.

As we watched the thrilling action movie, I was surprised by how the main character managed to escape every dangerous situation unscathed, making it hard for me to believe it could actually happen in real life.
After practicing for weeks, my soccer team celebrated our victory, especially since we played a tough game and finished without anyone getting hurt or feeling unscathed by the experience.

meanings: Not knowing something is happening or being unaware of important information. For example, if someone is unwittingly part of a surprise party, they don’t know the party is being planned for them.
examples: During our history project, I discovered that many unwitting explorers accidentally stumbled upon new lands, completely unaware of the impact their journeys would have on the world’s future.
When my little brother borrowed my video games without asking, he was unwittingly causing me frustration, not realizing how much I had been looking forward to playing them.
In science class, we learned that unwitting animals sometimes consume harmful plants, showing us just how important it is to understand what we put into our bodies.
While planning our community service event, I realized that some students were unwittingly spreading misinformation about our project, which made it important for us to clarify the details.

As we read the novel, we noticed that the main character was unwittingly making choices that would lead to surprising consequences, teaching us valuable lessons about decision-making and responsibility.

meanings: Urgent" means something that needs to be done right away or very soon because it is important. For example, if someone is hurt, it is urgent to get help quickly.
examples: When our science teacher announced that the project was due tomorrow, I felt an urgent need to finish my part quickly so my group could earn a good grade.
During the basketball game, my teammate got hurt, and the coach called for an urgent timeout to make sure he received medical attention right away.
As we watched the news about the wildfires, it became clear that helping the affected families was an urgent matter that required our community’s support and generosity.
While organizing my schedule for the week, I realized I had an urgent assignment due on Friday, so I had to prioritize my time to get everything done.
After discovering a leak in the kitchen, my parents acted with urgent determination to find and fix the problem before it caused any more damage to the house.

meanings: Verge" means the edge or boundary of something, like the side of a road or a garden. It can also refer to being close to a specific moment or event, like being on the verge of finishing a big project.
examples: As I stood on the verge of the diving board, my heart raced with excitement and fear, knowing that this moment would test my courage and determination to conquer my fear of heights.
After weeks of practice, our soccer team was on the verge of winning the championship, and the energy in the stadium was electric as our fans cheered us on with unwavering support.
In the science fair, I was on the verge of discovering a new way to create clean energy from simple household items, which could help reduce pollution and save our planet.
While reading my favorite book, I felt as if I was on the verge of entering a magical world, where anything was possible and adventures awaited at every turn of the page.
As my friends and I stood at the verge of the forest, we were filled with both curiosity and excitement about the hidden wonders and creatures that might be waiting for us inside.

meanings: Vigilant means being very careful and watchful, so you can notice anything that might be dangerous or wrong. It's like keeping your eyes open and paying attention, especially when you're in a new or risky situation.
examples: During the school safety drill, our teacher reminded us to be vigilant about listening for instructions so that we could respond quickly in case of an emergency.
As we explored the forest during our science field trip, we had to be vigilant for any signs of wildlife, ensuring we could observe animals without disturbing their natural habitats.
When playing soccer during practice, it’s important to remain vigilant, as staying aware of the movements of both teammates and opponents can greatly improve our chances of winning the game.
While working on our group project about ancient civilizations, we needed to be vigilant in our research, carefully checking facts to ensure we presented accurate information to the class.
As a responsible pet owner, I always stay vigilant when walking my dog, keeping an eye out for any potential dangers like busy streets or other animals that might cause trouble.

meanings: A vocation is a type of job or career that someone feels really passionate about and believes they are meant to do, often because it matches their talents and interests.
examples: When I grow up, I want to pursue a vocation in environmental science because I am passionate about protecting nature and finding ways to combat climate change for future generations.
My older sister chose a vocation as a teacher because she loves sharing her knowledge and inspiring young minds to discover their own passions and interests in life.
During our career day at school, I was fascinated to learn about the different vocations my classmates' parents had, from artists to engineers, and how each one played a vital role in society.
As I explore my interests in coding and design, I often think about how a vocation in technology could allow me to create video games that bring joy and excitement to others.
Volunteering at the animal shelter opened my eyes to the vocation of veterinary medicine, and I realized I could combine my love for animals with a fulfilling career helping them stay healthy.

meanings: Able to be easily hurt or harmed, either physically or emotionally, like when someone feels sad or scared because they are in a difficult situation.
examples: In science class, we learned that baby animals are often vulnerable to predators, which is why they stay close to their parents for protection when exploring their surroundings.
When a team loses a game, the players can feel vulnerable, but it’s important for them to support each other and learn from their mistakes to improve next time.
In the story we read, the hero felt vulnerable when facing the dragon alone, but he discovered that courage comes from believing in oneself and having friends by your side.

During our school assembly, we discussed how some students might feel vulnerable when sharing their feelings, so it’s essential to create a supportive environment where everyone feels safe and accepted.
While hiking in the woods, we noticed that certain plants are vulnerable to changes in the weather, which reminded us of the importance of protecting our environment for future generations.

meanings: To sing or make a sound that has a wavy or shaky quality, like a bird might do when it chirps happily.
examples: As I stood in the garden, I listened to the birds warble softly, their melodic tunes blending with the rustling leaves, creating a peaceful atmosphere that made me appreciate nature even more.
During our school concert, the choir's voices began to warble in harmony, filling the auditorium with beautiful sounds that made everyone in the audience smile and feel uplifted.
While playing video games with my friends, I noticed that the character I was controlling would occasionally warble a cheerful tune, adding to the fun and excitement of our gaming adventure.
In the early morning, the sun peeked through my window, and I could hear the sparrows outside warble happily, reminding me that a brand-new day was waiting for us to explore and enjoy.
While reading my favorite book about the forest, I imagined the little creatures warble their songs, creating a magical soundtrack that made the story come alive in my imagination.

meanings: Being wary means being careful and alert about things that might be risky or dangerous, like when you feel unsure about trying something new or meeting someone you don't know well.
examples: When exploring the dark woods behind our school, I felt wary of the unfamiliar sounds and shadows, knowing that it was important to stay alert and safe during our adventure.
During the science fair, I was wary of the judges' questions, so I practiced my presentation multiple times to ensure I could explain my project clearly and confidently.
As the new student approached our lunch table, we all felt a bit wary, wondering if he would fit in with our group or if he might be shy and reserved.
While biking down the steep hill, I was wary of the rough patches on the path, reminding myself to slow down and keep my balance to avoid any accidents.
After hearing about the recent storm that caused power outages in our neighborhood, my parents became wary of the weather forecast and decided to prepare an emergency kit just in case.

meanings: To gradually stop giving a baby animal or child milk so that they learn to eat regular food instead.
examples: As the puppy grew older, its owner decided it was time to wean it off milk, introducing solid food to ensure it received a balanced diet for healthy growth.
In science class, we learned that farmers often wean their calves from their mothers to encourage independence and promote strong development in young cattle.
My mom said that when we wean our kitten from its bottle, it will be able to join us at the dinner table and enjoy real cat food with the rest of us.
After weeks of training, the coach decided it was time to wean the players off their reliance on their star teammate, encouraging them to develop their own skills and teamwork.
In the story we read, the wise old owl helped the baby birds wean from their nest, teaching them how to fly and find food on their own in the big, wide world.

meanings: A whim is a sudden idea or wish that comes to mind without much planning. It’s like when you suddenly want to eat ice cream even if it’s not dessert time!
examples: On a whim, I decided to write a short story about a dragon who befriends a lonely knight, and it turned out to be the best creative writing assignment I’ve ever completed.
My brother often chooses to play video games on a whim, which sometimes leads to epic gaming marathons that last all weekend and leave us both exhausted but happy.
During our science project, we made a last-minute decision on a whim to build a volcano instead of a simple poster, and it ended up being the highlight of our presentation.
While walking through the park, I spotted a beautiful butterfly and, on a whim, I decided to follow it, discovering a hidden garden filled with colorful flowers and unique plants.
We were planning a quiet evening at home, but on a whim, my friends and I decided to organize a surprise party for our classmate, making it an unforgettable night filled with laughter and joy.

meanings: Wrath is a very strong and intense anger that can make someone want to get back at others for something they did. It’s like feeling really mad when you think something unfair has happened to you.
examples: When the teacher discovered that someone had cheated on the test, the look of wrath on her face made it clear that she expected better behavior from her students.
During the soccer game, the coach's wrath was evident when he saw his players arguing instead of working together, reminding them that teamwork is crucial for success.
After losing the final round of the video game tournament, Jason felt a wave of wrath wash over him, but he realized that getting angry wouldn't help him improve for next time.
The hero in the book faced the villain's wrath after discovering that his actions had harmed innocent people, prompting him to seek justice and make things right.
When my sister borrowed my favorite book without asking and then accidentally spilled juice on it, my wrath was overwhelming, but I knew I had to forgive her eventually.

meanings: Zest is a strong feeling of excitement and energy that makes you really enjoy doing something. It's like having a lot of passion for a hobby or activity that makes it even more fun!
examples: When we started our science project, my partner and I approached it with zest, eager to explore the fascinating world of ecosystems and create a model that would impress our classmates.
During the school talent show, Sarah performed her dance routine with such zest that the audience couldn't help but cheer and clap along, inspiring others to join in the fun.
As we hiked up the mountain trail, my friends and I felt an overwhelming zest for adventure, excitedly pointing out the different plants and animals we encountered along the way.
In history class, our teacher shared stories of great explorers, and I listened with zest, imagining the thrilling adventures they experienced while discovering new lands and cultures.
While working on our art project, I added bright colors and bold patterns with zest, hoping to capture the attention of my classmates and inspire them to express their own creativity.
